name: Academy FC, Cornell (CAFC)
description:
Previously, Cornell men’s club soccer had three soccer teams for which students could try out for: Cornell Mundial FC, CUFC (Arsenal), and Cornell United. Each team carried about thirty students on their roster for eleven starting positions each game. Hundreds of students made their way to the fields behind Appel with the goal of being given one of a handful of spots that each soccer club had available. Appel fields were so packed with hopeful club members that only those players that excelled in small spaces could make a name for themselves during tryouts. These select few players with high individual skill succeeded in joining one of the three club teams available. Those players that did not excel on a soccer field packed with hundreds of players were left without a team to further pursue the sport that they may have been playing for their entire lives. We do not believe that the logistics of this process or the evaluation criteria were optimal.

Prior to the creation of Cornell Academy FC, Cornell men’s club soccer has only two soccer teams: Cornell Mundial FC and Cornell Santos. At a university that consists of over 14,300+ undergraduate students, sixty club soccer spots is not nearly enough for Cornell University to provide to their soccer community. With only two teams this fall instead of the three teams that Cornell had last fall, more hopeful students will be left off of a club soccer team because, with only 11 starting positions per team, there are only so many players that a club team can hold on their roster.
 
The following is the ratio of undergraduate student population to club soccer teams at our Ivy peers in ascending order: Princeton- 2650 undergraduate students to one club soccer team, Harvard- 3600 undergraduate students to one club soccer team, Dartmouth- 4200 undergraduate students to one club soccer team, Yale- 5400 undergraduate students to one club soccer team, UPenn- 10300 undergraduate students to one club soccer team. Columbia and Brown do not participate in club soccer. The average of our ivy peers that do participate in club soccer is 5230 undergraduate students per club soccer team.
 
Cornell is significantly above the average (at about 7150) and is above every ivy except for UPenn. We believe that as Cornell continues to approach the ratio at UPenn, there will be fewer opportunities for readily interested soccer players from participating actively. We aim to create the greatest amount of opportunities for these players. Furthermore, we believe that exclusivity should not be a primary determining factor of success of Cornell Sports Clubs, as it is not in Cornell’s approach to academics.

The reason for the merger of Cornell United and CUFC (Arsenal) into one soccer team would initially appear to make sense: one team will have more talent than two separate teams and this greater level of talent will therefore win more games. However, this logic is flawed in that talent alone does not win games: hard work and team work does. Cornell Academy FC will not only replace the void left by the lack of a third team at Cornell this fall, but also this club’s purpose is to both provide a club soccer team to those athletes overlooked by the traditional club soccer tryout system and to fundamentally change the relationship between Cornell club soccer and the non-club soccer community at Cornell. The athletes that that Cornell club soccer community does not currently provide for are those that may lack the individual, flashy skill that would differentiate them in a tryout of hundreds of players but that have the qualities most important to forming a successful team: selflessness, passion, work ethic, and soccer IQ. Additionally, under the current club soccer regime at Cornell, there is tremendous separation and exclusivity between club soccer teams and the non-club soccer community at Cornell. It is Cornell Academy FC’s purpose to further unite these two separate communities by allowing students to tryout for our team at any point during the academic year by attending practices. These practices will allow for non-club members to feel included and given a fair chance to join the very exclusive club soccer system at Cornell. This will also allow for more opportunities for non-club members to train and potentially qualify for our team. Even with our approval, Cornell club soccer will still have countless students who wish to play soccer but did not make a club soccer team. By reaching out to the non-club Cornell community, Cornell Academy FC will help solve this problem.

name: ACE: The Ace/Asexual Support Group at Cornell
description: ACE is a student-run social support group for individuals of the Cornell community who identify as ace or ace-questioning. ACE provides its members with a support network and a safe space to meet and discuss ace related issues and experiences. ACE is also dedicated to developing the ace community at Cornell and improving visibility and availability of information surrounding the ace community.

name: Aerial Robotics, Cornell University
description: The purpose of the Aerial Robotics Club at Cornell University is to promote competency in the development of UAVs and allow students the opportunity to apply educational concepts towards real-world applications.

name: African Dance Repertoire
description: To foster the awareness of African cultures through music, dance, and theatrical performances both on and off campus.

name: African Development Association
description: The organization will spread awareness about African issues regarding education, violence, human rights, environmental change, health, and others is key to inspire change. Motivated students, made aware from campaigns, will then be expected to devise fundraising activities to implement outreach projects.

name: ALANA Intercultural Programming Board
description: We seek to provide the Cornell community with wide and diversified programming on a regular basis as well as allocate funds to registered student organizations for programs that encourage diversity and intercultural efforts.

name: Algoer, Cornell
description:
CAR serves as the bridge between Computer Science academia and industry for Cornell students. The academia and industry have very different goals and mindsets. Many students wishing to enter the CS industry have limited interview experience. With an increasingly competitive job market, the overabundance of programmers, and lack of training, we find talent students failing interviews. To tackle the problems before graduation, CAR connects students with alumni already working in top technical companies, and CAR helps them practice technical questions. Furthermore, CAR would try to do industrial projects to help students get practical skills. CAR would research on big data topics closely related to jobs and interviews. 

The fundamental missions of are as follows:

Hold weekly meetings to video chat with industry gurus.
Hold weekly meetings to solve Leetcode problems.
Hold interview tech talk.
Develop CS projects regularly.
Publish data report regularly.

name: Alpha Epsilon Delta; Pre-medical Honors Society
Alpha Epsilon Honors Society of Biological and Environmental Engineering
Alpha Eta Rho-Chi Upsilon
description: Alpha Eta Rho is an intercollegiate organization that serves as a contact between the aviation industry and education institutions to foster, promote, and mentor student leaders through education, charity, scholarship and service, towards successful professional careers in the aviation field and all of its branches. Membership in Alpha Eta Rho is open to all collegiate men and women who share a common purpose and have a strong active interest in any field within the aviation and aerospace industries.

name: Alpha Iota Gamma Gamma Chapter
description: Alpha Iota Gamma (Α I Γ) serves as a professional, academic, and social foundation for men and women dedicated to pursuing a career in healthcare. The brothers and sisters of Alpha Iota Gamma uphold a commitment to discipline, compassion, and integrity, key ethical pillars in healthcare and life. The bonds formed in Alpha Iota Gamma between students with diverse healthcare interests creates a comprehensive network at the undergraduate level and beyond. Members of Alpha Iota Gamma have the opportunity to meet other students interested in healthcare careers, get peer and professional level advice from other members and invited speakers, be involved in philanthropy and social events, and most importantly make friendships that will last years after graduating from Cornell.

American Civil Liberties Union, The Cornell University Chapter of the
description: To educate the Cornell community about their civil liberties and to guard against the erosion of said liberties.

name: American Mock World Health Organization Cornell
American Red Cross
description: Founded in 1901, the Cornell Chapter of Alpha Zeta is a co-ed, honors, professional, and social fraternity for anyone with an interest in agriculture. We provide a unique community on campus that provides opportunities for community service, social activities, and professional networking. The goals of our Fraternity are to foster high standards of scholarship, character, leadership, and fellowship and also to promote the advancement of agriculture. Our main agricultural outreach event, Ag Day, is held every semester and brings farm animals and agricultural equipment to the Ag Quad to expose the Cornell community to and educate them about agriculture. We also hold a number of philanthropy events every year which contribute to a handful of organizations including the 4-H Foundation, the American Red Cross, Heifer International, Adopt-a-Highway, and the Special Olympics.

name: American Society of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology - Cornell Chapter
description: The Cornell Chapter of ASBMB has a mission of increasing interest in the field of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, specifically in underrepresented groups in science of the undergraduate community. Additionally, the organization has goals to increase awareness of research happening at Cornell to students of biology and bring scientific awareness and knowledge to the Ithaca community.

name: American Society of Landscape Architects Cornell Chapter
Anabel Taylor Chapel Choir
description: The performance of sacred music in liturgical and concert settings, and the development of musical skills and leadership among participants.

name: Angel Capital Club, Cornell
description: The Cornell Angel Capital Club (CACC) is a student-run organization that promotes Cornell undergraduates of all disciplines by providing them with an unparalleled opportunity to learn about entrepreneurship, intellectual property, business models, business formation, business capitalization, business strategy, private investment, venture capital investment, and other business-related areas and skills through CACC’s relationship with its Angel Investment Groups and their Portfolio Companies, through the services CACC provides to its Angel Investment Groups and their Portfolio Companies, through the tutelage of advisors and senior members of the Club, and through guest speakers on topics related to the Club’s interests and activities.

name: Applied Physics Graduate Society
description: The purpose of the APGS is to facilitate communication among the applied physics graduate students as well as the broader Cornell community. Our goals include disseminating important information to graduate students and acting as a formal voice for graduate students within the workings of the department. Additionally, the APGS fosters community among physics graduate students by organizing social events and discussion forums.

name: Archery Club, Cornell
description: The Cornell Archery Club provides a forum for the discussion and practice of the traditional sport of archery.  Our charge is to promote an environment where any and all members of the Cornell community can participate in a classic sport and learn the elements of collegiate archery. In pursuit of this goal, we facilitate weekly shoots, where archers of all skill levels can practice and socialize, learning from more experienced archers and developing their own skills and their understanding of the sport. We also attend local, state and national competitions for members who are interested in competing.

name: Argentine and Uruguayan Friends at Cornell
Art Beyond Cornell
description: The mission of Art Beyond Cornell is to create and carry out artistic projects for participants of the MacCormick Secure Center and share those initiatives with the Cornell community. Within this, we hope to also cultivate an awareness of American carceral systems of their real-time consequences.

name: Art Majors Organization
description: AMO facilitates the exchange of ideas between art students of all years in the Cornell University Art Department. It brings together a community for artists to cultivate, foster, and encourage passion, and an interest in fine art. The club hosts events geared toward encouraging interactions between art students -undergraduates and graduates alike.

name: Asia Real Estate Society, Cornell
description: The mission of the Cornell Asia Real Estate Society is to connect Real Estate research and business interests in the United States and Asia.

name: Association of Computer Science Undergraduates
description: The Association of Computer Science Undergraduates (ACSU) promotes educational, professional, and social interaction among every undergraduate student interested in computer science.

These extramural opportunities will not only promote better officiating through increasing overall knowledge of respective sports but also provide transferable job-related skills and encourage cooperative attitudes and working relationships.

name: AXSigma - Alpha Chi Sigma

Our organization seeks to bring together people interested in chemistry, both to advance the science of chemistry and to advance the goals of those interested in the field. 
We reach out to youth organizations to try to raise interest in chemistry, and we connect our members to a diverse network of alumni whose goals and interests align with those of our current members.

description: The Cornell Beekeeping Club provides opportunities to learn beekeeping in a hands-on setting. Outreach and group collaboration are major goals for the growth of our club.

Biomedical Engineering Women's Group

description: Our organization's unique mission is to educate and spur interest for Biomedical Informatics through activities like faculty seminars, research project teams, and biomedical data hackathons. For faculty seminars, we would bring in professors to present on their work and hold Q&A's after their talks. Research project teams are an integral component of the club that allows students to work on projects devised by Cornell faculty. We also conduct data hackathons where students build analytic pipelines for various open genomic datasets. Such events and activities would help them stay abreast of the state of the art.

description: To provide opportunities for students who enjoy birding and ornithology, including birding field trips, faculty lectures, and social events.

Black and Latino Intervarsity is a specific division of Intervarsity on Cornell University’s campus that is committed to aiding students and faculty of color in their walk with Jesus as they explore God and faith through open dialogues, bible studies, small groups, and community involvement.

name: Black and Latino Media, Cornell University
description: The mission of CUBAL Media is to solve the scheduling issues of the POC community at Cornell, specifically with regards to event planning. Additionally, there is a big problem in the way that students have access to these events. It is often the case that students must scroll through dozens of event flyers to find which events they want to go. CUBAL Media will solve that by centralizing all of these things on one platform.

description: BBMTA of Cornell University is a non-profit organization dedicated to serving underrepresented students interested in pursuing health-related careers. The organization provides underrepresented students with a community and resources to succeed as pre-health undergraduate students. BBMTA hosts general body meetings where students obtain academic support, professional development skills and awareness of health-related issues. Through our annual health career conference composed of panels and workshops, we expose students to a range of health professionals and give students the opportunity to engage with those already established in the medical field. BBMTA extends its mission into the Ithaca community beyond Cornell through commitment to various service projects and youth mentorship.

name: Black Entrepreneurs in Training
description:
To foster entrepreneurial culture in underrepresented communities through our commitment to
diversity, experiential learning, and fellowship.

name: Black Graduate Professional Student Association
description: BGPSA is a network that addresses the needs and concerns of graduate and professional students of African descent at Cornell University. BGPSA involves itself in social, academic, and cultural activities deemed relevant as determined by the voting body. BGPSA works closely with underrepresented faculty and staff and is involved in issues that affect Ithaca’s Black community. BGPSA will do all things necessary and appropriate to accomplish these purposes.

Blueprint 2 Building

name: Board of Portfolio Managers, Cornell
description: The purpose of our organization is to teach members how to think and manage a portfolio like an investment professional. During our meetings we discuss our different investing strategies and subject our best investment ideas to the scrutiny of the rest of the club.

name: Bowling Club, Cornell
description: The mission of Cornell Bowling Club is to provide Cornell community members of all skill levels with an opportunity to bowl recreationally and/or competitively throughout their college careers.

name: Boxing Club at Cornell University
description: The Cornell Boxing Club aims to provide a safe, supportive, and fun environment for any interested student to learn the sport of boxing.

Bread n' Butter

We want to bring to light these problems on our campus and work towards solutions while fostering inclusion and extending dialogue. Our pantry is run by our executive board as well as student volunteers from various organizations on-campus.

name: Bridge Club, Cornell
description: Cornell Bridge Club aims to introduce people to the wonderful game of bridge, as well as to enhance the skills of people who already know the game.

name: Building Ourselves Through Sisterhood and Service Peer Mentorship Program
Canoe, Cornell
description: The club fields teams to practice and compete in competitive and open touring canoe races throughout the United States. We accomplish this through the development of paddling skills, endurance training, and logistical preparations before given events.

name: Caribbean Student Association Dance Ensemble, Cornell
Caribbean Students' Association
description: The purpose of the CSA is to raise the level of awareness at Cornell University, and in the surrounding colleges and community, of the cultural diversity of all Caribbean nations. This organization represents the views, beliefs, culture, and politics of the Caribbean students, staff, and faculty. We strive to celebrate Caribbean culture and create a safe space for students who identify with Caribbean culture to embrace and share their culture.

name: Celtic Club, Cornell
description: To promote the Celtic traditions of Ireland, Scotland, Wales, Breton and Cape Breton, particularly through dance and music.

name: Centroamericanos Unidos Student Association
description: Centroamericanos Unidos Student Association's mission is to create a community and network among all Central Americans at Cornell and those interested in Central American issues by providing cultural, social, political, and educational activities and programs.

name: CFI - Cornellians For Israel  (Previously - Israel Public Affairs Committee)
description: CFI serves as the bipartisan pro-Israel voice on campus. CFI programs, speakers, and activities center on Israel awareness, culture, education, and advocacy. CFI is dedicated to positively impact campus, Congress, and Israel by bringing effective Israel programming to the Cornell community. CFI is a place where all students can meet, plan events, and make a difference.

name: Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering Graduate Women's Group
description: The CBEGWG is an organizational unit whose purpose is 1) to focus on issues pertinent to female affiliates of the School of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, and 2) to encourage young girls to enter engineering through outreach.

name: China-U.S. Cultural Exchange Association of Cornell
description:
China-U.S. Cultural Exchange Association of Cornell aims to facilitate American and Chinese cultural exchange between students both in and out of Cornell. We wish to provide more platforms for those who are interested in Chinese or American culture to meet and exchange ideas, goals, and philosophy. Our association provides regular networking and learning activities, including but not limited to social events, seminars, language-learning opportunities, debates, and competitions. We will also arrange an annual cultural exchange conference in either China or the United States. It is our hope that we will enhance and inspire both US and Chinese future leaders to better understand our cultures.

The organization's activities include but not limited to:

1. Research with professor program + RMD (winter and summer)

Professor from top universities will join the program to teach lectures about different research project. Additionally, professors and students ambassadors will join the program to share their research related experiences. Chinese students will work on a research project under the guidance of American team. Chinese students will learn both academically and culturally by interacting with American culture.

2. Model WTO

CUCEA launched Model World Trade Organization (Mode WTO). Model WTO is an authentic simulation of the WTO General Assembly, WTO Security Council, or other multilateral body, which introduces students to the world of diplomacy, negotiation, and decision-making. 

3. China-U.S. Academic and Social Events

Anyone who is interested in learning Chinese or making Chinese friends can come to the events. There will be speed dating, cultural topic discussions, and free chatting sessions in the social events.

4. Cultural Projects Incubator

This social event gives people a chance to meet potential Chinese or US partners to start an international project. The project can be but not limited to a business idea, a charity, a cultural exchange program, etc. There will be a pitch time which people can pitch their ideas in front of a group of people. If there are other people interested, they can discuss during and after the events. This event also gives people a chance to ask different opinions from people with different cultural backgrounds.

name: Chinese Drama Society, Cornell
description: We aim to promote theatre performances in Chinese language at Cornell University, through regular performances and other exchanges, to provide performing arts entertainment for the Chinese-speaking community (including language learners) and to diversify the multi-cultural performing arts scene at Cornell. We are an independent student organization registered with Cornell University.

name: Chinese Entrepreneur Association at Cornell
description: The purpose of our organization is to foster the entrepreneurial spirit among our members, to assist in the personal growth and career development related to entrepreneurship among our members individually and collectively, to connect and help to connect our members internally at Cornell and externally with entrepreneurs, investors, alumni and any person related to the our purpose.

name: Chinese Students and Scholars Association, Cornell
Christian Union, Cornell (Previously - Faith and Action)
Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints Student Association
Cinema Student Advisory Board, Cornell University
Classics Society, Cornell
description: The Cornell Classics Society aims to both promote and nurture interest in the Classics and related fields in a more casual environment than that offered in the classroom.

name: Club Golf, Cornell University
description:
The purpose of the Cornell Club Golf Team is to combine as a unit of competitive golfers in the Cornell community to grow in our appreciation and expertise of the game. The Cornell  Golf Team will conform to the uniform system of handicapping and rules set forth by the United States Golf Association. The Club Golf Team will be committed to the traditions and history of the game and compete on a national level as members of the National Collegiate Club Golf Association.

The organization will meet weekly at the Robert Trent Jones Golf course in order to practice as well as discuss and organize upcoming tournaments.

name: Club Rowing, Cornell
description: We provide an opportunity for all past and new rowers a chance to get back on the water. The goal of the team is to foster discipline, focus, and friendship on and off the water.  We compete in various local regattas through the Cascadilla Boat Club (CBC). As a competitive team, hard work is expected.

name: Cog Dog Theatre Troupe
description: The purpose of the Cog Dog Theatre Troupe is to put on theatre that provokes reflection, creates discussion and (hopefully) inspires action and change.  In particular, our being independent allows us to put on types of theatre and specific shows that aren't possible at Risley or Schwartz.

name: Collegiate Association for the Realization of Peace - Cornell Chapter
description: To practice different aspects of Unification Thought through service and creating a culture of peace and understanding among a diverse group of students. It is a community that stresses the importance of personal excellence and interpersonal relationships to create strong families, societies and nations that can encompass the vision of world peace and unification across all borders of race, religion, and culture.

name: Collegiate New York Farm Bureau at Cornell University
Collegiate Scholars, The National Society of
Committee for the Advancement of Muslim Culture
description:
1) To oversee the Muslim Life Space and plan social events as the social arm of MECA
2) To provide social resources for anyone interested in Islam or who identifies as Muslim 
3) To showcase the richness & diversity of Islam/Muslim cultures to the greater Cornell community

name: Community Partnership Funding Board
description: The Community Partnership Funding Board (CPFB), is a student-run board that seeks to foster student leadership and social responsibility by encouraging students to take action against social inequities. CPFB assists students in developing grassroots community action projects and administers grants of up to $2,500 made possible by the Student Activities Fee through the Student Assembly.

name: Comparative Cultures and Literature Forum
description:
The Comparative Culture and Literature Forum is the organization of graduate students in the Department of Comparative Literature. CCLF acts as the voice of graduate students in the department and the university at large.

In addition to organizing and/or funding a variety of intradepartmental events including Graduate Student Colloquia, Graduate Instructor Pedagogy Workshops, the Book-in-Common Project and monthly workshops on graduate and professional life, CCLF also enriches the broader Cornell community by organizing public lectures and seminars with new and visiting faculty and post-doctoral fellows (Speaker Series) and prominent, extramural invited speakers whose work exemplifies the best of contemporary comparative and theoretical work in the Humanities.

name: Compass: The Cornell & George Junior Republic Partnership
description:
Our organization functions in association with and with support from Cornell’s Public Service Center and the George Junior Republic High School (GJR). Our objectives are:
1.	To centralize the needs and interests of the GJR students in the development and maintenance of quality after-school programming

2.	To serve as an umbrella organization for the Poetic Justice and computer science clubs, as well as any other organizations that the high school students seek to initiate through a partnership with Cornell

3.	To critically reflect on off-campus civic engagement and the larger systems in which we enact such engagement

4.	To nourish a reciprocal partnership in which Cornell students both provide resources for and learn from GJR students

5.	To provide support and opportunities for personal reflection to all Compass members

6.	To serve as a gatekeeper to the GJR after-school programs and provide support for other students, classes or professors who may wish to engage with Compass organizations

7.	To coordinate and maintain strong communication channels with with GJR teachers program co-facilitators (i.e. the Math and Literacy Coaches)

8.	To provide educational opportunities for the Cornell community, and especially Compass members, on broader systems of oppression – such as socioeconomic status, racial identity, gender identity, sexuality, ability status, etc. – that contribute to the disenfranchisement of many of the GJR students

9.	To counteract that disenfranchisement and empower GJR students by providing them a platform for creativity, learning, and leadership

name: Contemporary Chamber Players, Cornell
description: The Cornell Contemporary Chamber Players presents an annual concert series, featuring the music of Cornell graduate composers. The series, typically consisting of three events a year, is an integral component of the composers' experience at Cornell and provides a critical environment for collaborations with professional musicians both inside and outside of Ithaca. Since its inception, CCCP has been dedicated its efforts to showcasing world premieres by Cornell's emerging composers.

name: Contemporary German Literature Reading Group
description: Participation in our group provides additional opportunities to explore contemporary German-language literature in a supportive, informal academic setting. We meet four times per term to discuss German literature published within the last decade. Our aim is to forge a dialogue about contemporary literature and culture from outside the US beyond departmental lines and outside the traditional classroom. Though the group's current membership consists primarily of graduate students and faculty in German Studies, we welcome advanced undergraduate students, graduate students, and faculty of any department to join us for our discussions.

name: Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine Student Chapter of the World Aquatic Veterinary Medical Association
description: The purpose of the CUCVM Dance Collective is to bring together the dance community within the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine by celebrating our enthusiasm for art, music, and dance.  As a non-audition based dance group open to students of any level and style of dance, we serve as a creative outlet for students who would like a fun and casual way to express movement and meet others with similar interests during our bi-monthly open classes.  In addition to this, the CUCVM Dance Collective also offers performance opportunities to those students who would like the chance to choreograph and perform.  Such opportunities include our annual Spring Showcase, which provides student choreographers a venue where they can present their work to the entire community.

name: Cosmic, Cornell
description: Cornell Cosmic will analyze and debate  the future of outer space through numerous fields, including both humanities and STEM, such as law, astronomy, sociology, and political science, among many others. We will publish a journal each year regarding the most forefront news in outer space.

name: Cricket Club, Cornell
description: The Cricket Club at Cornell seeks to promote the game of cricket amongst the Cornell and Ithaca community by arranging matches and regular practice sessions for players of the game, and introducing it to new players. We also seek to play competitive matches against other university teams and compete in national level tournaments to promote the game to a broader US audience.

name: Cross-Cultural Adoptee Mentorship Program
description: Cross-Cultural Adoptee Mentorship Program (C-CAMP) is a student-run outreach program of the Cornell University Public Service Center (PSC). We were founded in 2007 to promote cultural understanding and appreciation of internationally-adopted youth in Tompkins County. The program matches Cornell students with cross-culturally adopted mentees who share the same culture and heritage. The mentor-mentee pairings develop sustainable relationships that allow for a mutual exploration of their cultural identities. Also, the public outreach events such as Dinner and Discussion/Lunch and Learn integrate our mission of education and cultural growth with the broader community. C-CAMP is funded in part by the Student Assembly Finance Commission (SAFC) and the ALANA Intercultural Board, and is partnered with the Adoptive and Foster Family Coalition of New York (AFFCNY) and Adoption and Guardianship Assistance Program for Everyone (AGAPE).

name: Crossword Club at Cornell
description: Cornell's Crossword Club is focused on all things crossword. Our goal is to contribute to members' intellectual growth in a fun way by meeting and completing crossword puzzles. We plan to provide copies of the New York Times crossword for members and distribute information on events such as the Finger Lakes Crossword Competition.

name: CU IMAGE - Increasing Multicultural Admissions and Gains in Enrollment, Cornell University
Cuban American Student Association
description: The Cuban American Student Association (CASA) is an organization that is dedicated to the discussion of cultural, social, and political issues concerning Cubans in and around the Cornell community and nationwide. It provides academic and emotional support for Cubans at Cornell and educates the Cornell community about issues concerning Cubans.

name: Curly Initiative
description: The purpose of The Curly Initiative is to unite people of color over their hair and educate others about hair practices within and beyond the Cornell campus, while hosting and co-hosting events that resonate with our mission.

name: Dance, Cornell (formerly Big Red Dance Squad)
Darts Club at Cornell
description: We want to bring together students who are interested in the sport of darts and provide a place for them to improve their skills and understanding of the game.

name: Dead Poets Society
description:
The Dead Poets Society was started in response to the need for a creative, poetic outlet for Cornell University undergraduate students. It represents the ideals that any student is capable of pursuing any study, and for us it is the study, creation, analysis, and the appreciation of poetry by any medium and by students of any ability. This club was established for the people and by the people, and with it, we hope to foster a love for the greatness ingrained within poetry. 
Goals
To foster a nurturing and safe environment for appreciating, listening to, and creating poetry
To make a space to share these creations, either by an online or physical medium
To provide an outlet for the creative versions of ourselves that are not always able to be cultivated within our respective studies

name: Deaf Awareness Project, Cornell University
description: The Cornell University Deaf Awareness Project (CUDAP) is a student-run program of the Cornell Public Service Center. Our mission has three parts: first, we aim to promote heightened awareness of the Deaf community, culture and history. Second, we hope to support a welcoming environment for students to learn about the Deaf community and American Sign Language (ASL) through meetings and events, while encouraging understanding and interaction between the Cornell campus and Deaf and Hard of Hearing persons. Finally, we hope to support the ASL course sequence offered by Cornell University during the school year.

name: Debate in Science and Health (Previously - Debate in Sciences and Health)
Delta Kappa Alpha Professional Cinematic Society
Department of Natural Resources Graduate Student Assembly
Design and Environmental Analysis Graduate Student Association
description: The purpose of this organization is to foster community amongst graduate DEA students and to set up events which would be beneficial academically and professionally.

name: Design by Biomedical Undergraduate Teams (DEBUT), Cornell
Development Sociology Graduate Student Collective
description: This organization is designed to help organize and fund activities for graduate students interested in the field of Development Sociology and to support graduate student exposure to the field.

name: Dickson and McLLU Hall Council
description: To promote the formation of a community and foster interaction, a sense of unity, and respect for others through social, cultural, and education programming. To serve as representative for the resident of complex and the residential student congress.

name: Dietetics Association, Cornell University
description: The mission of the Cornell University Dietetic Association is to (1) create and maintain a network and sense of community among Cornell dietetics students, faculty, staff, and alumni as well as facilitate a strong relationship with student, state, and national dietetic associations; (2) explore/raise awareness of dietetics education and internships.

name: Diplomat, The Cornell
description: The purpose of The Cornell Diplomat magazine is to engage with the Cornell student body by connecting it with contrasting perspectives on today’s most pressing international issues.

name: Disability Design Club, Cornell
description: Our purpose is to develop an engineering solution that would benefit people with disabilities in their community.

name: Doctors without Borders at Cornell
description: In May 1968, a group of young doctors decided to go and help victims of wars and major disasters. This new brand of humanitarianism would reinvent the concept of emergency aid. They were to become Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF), known internationally in English as Doctors Without Borders. Today, MSF has medical projects in over 70 countries around the world addressing global health problems ranging from access to medicines, malnutrition to Ebola and antibiotic resistance.

name: Dragon Boat Club, Cornell
description: Our purpose is to share the sport of dragon boat with the Cornell Community

name: DSOC Undergraduate Student Organization
description: The organization aims to create a Development Sociology (DSOC) community in which undergraduates can network with graduate students, faculty, and alumni, mentor one another, and provide resources for internship and job opportunities.

name: Dyson News Discussion
description: This organization will have as its purpose to holistically benefit the Dyson community, by fostering collaboration between members and allowing students to receive awareness on fundamental current news updates regarding the world around them.

name: Early Modern Reading Group
description: The Early Modern Reading Group focuses on texts concerned with the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, with an interdisciplinary approach involving material from literature, history, film, philosophy, and art. We seek to foster a lively and expansive discussion of early modern thought and culture by cooperatively analyzing primary, secondary, and theoretical works. The Early Modern Reading Group also works in conjunction with the Gottschalk Memorial Lecture to host an annual symposium in the fall.

name: Early Music Lab, Cornell
description: The purpose of Cornell Early Music Lab is to promote early music at Cornell University through performance, outreach and education, and collaborative projects.

name: EARS - Empathy Assistance and Referral Service
Earth and Atmospheric Science Student Association
East Coast Asian American Student Union at Cornell University
description: The East Coast Asian American Student Union (ECAASU) is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit whose mission is to inspire, educate, and empower those interested in Asian American and Pacific Islander (AAPI) issues. Run solely by volunteers, ECAASU’s advocacy work is conducted through outreach to AAPI students organizations across the country and educating individuals on becoming agents of change through the various programs we hold over the course of the year, including an annual conference.

name: Eastern Music Ensemble, Cornell
description: The Cornell Eastern Music Ensemble brings together lovers of East Asian music, and promotes wider awareness and deeper understanding of Asian culture through performance. Our repertoire includes genres such as traditional Chinese, Asian popular music, film soundtracks, and even East-West fusion. We showcase the rare talents and exotic instruments of musicians to encourage student growth beyond the standard curriculum.

name: Ecology and Evolutionary Biology Graduate Student Association
Economics Society, Cornell
description:
The Cornell Economics Society (CES) is the largest and longest running undergraduate economics and pre-business society at Cornell. Hundreds of undergraduate members and alumni share a passion for the study of economics and its applications. As a society, we exist not only to serve the academic needs of our members but also to serve as a guide to attaining their professional goals and to provide a sense of community through events such as the mentorship program, networking sessions, exploratory seminars in diverse fields in Economics, and the annual Econ Week, which is a beginner's guide to navigating Economics at Cornell University.

The Cornell Economics Society also publishes Cornell Undergraduate Economic Review (CUER), an undergraduate peer reviewed economics journal. For more information about CUER, please visit the publications page of the website.

name: Education Services for the Incarcerated, Cornell
description: The purpose of this organization is to connect Cornell students to Adult Education students at the Tompkins County Jail. Cornell students will tutor inmates in preparation for their TASC test (High School Equivalency Test).

name: Effective Altruism, Cornell
description: The club is organized around the principle of using third party research on the effectiveness of charitable donations to improve the impact of charitable acts.  The purpose of this specific club on campus is to educate the Cornell community about these ideas and methods, fundraise for well-researched causes, and outreach to other public service organizations on campus to discuss how to have the most positive impact on the global community.

name: Elderly Partnership, Cornell
description: The mission of the Cornell Elderly Partnership (CEP) is to facilitate the creation and maintenance of relationships, interaction, and mutual learning between students and elders in the Ithaca community.

name: Electron Devices Society
description: The primary purpose of the society is to meet every week to listen to a colleague explain his or her research. This creates valuable opportunities for researchers to practice giving technical presentations and to generate new research collaborations. Additional guest speakers from inside or outside Cornell may be invited to speak on technical or non-technical topics of interest to the EDS community. Occasional social events may be organized through EDS but the primary purpose is to generate scholarly discussion of science and engineering.

name: ENG - American Indian Science and Engineering Society
ENG - American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Cornell University
ENG - American Institute of Chemical Engineers
ENG - American Society of Civil Engineers
ENG - American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Cornell University Chapter
description: Cornell ASME aims to enrich the lives of students of the Sibley School by providing professional and social networking events, information about post-graduation career paths, and local outreach activities. We uphold the ASME mission to serve diverse global communities by advancing, disseminating and applying engineering knowledge for improving the quality of life, and communicating the excitement of engineering.

name: ENG - Chemical Engineering Graduate Student Association
ENG - Civil and Environmental Engineering Graduate Student Association
ENG - eMed: Society of Engineers in Medicine
ENG - Encourage Young Engineers and Scientists
ENG - Engineers for a Sustainable World
ENG - Engineers Without Borders Cornell University Chapter
ENG - Inspiring Chemical Engineers
description: Inspiring Chemical Engineers (ICE) aims to raise interest in chemical engineering and related STEM fields. We want young students to realize that engineering is even more fun and exciting than it is challenging. We plan to host interactive seminars and demonstrations in local schools and science centers. ICE is a great way for anyone interested in science and engineering to practice teaching, make new friends, and give back to the local community.

name: ENG - Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE)
ENG - National Society of Black Engineers-Cornell University
ENG - Seismic Design  (Previously -Earthquake Engineering Research Institute Undergraduate Seismic Design Project Team)
ENG - Society of Asian Scientists and Engineers
ENG - Society of Hispanic Professional Engineers - Cornell Chapter
ENG - Society of Women Engineers, Cornell University
ENG - Steel Bridge Project Club, Cornell
ENG - Under-Represented Minorities in Computing at Cornell
English Graduate Student Organization
description: EGSO is the field organization for graduate students in the department of English Language and Literature that works to foster intellectual community and social interaction among English graduate students.

name: Ethiopian-Eritrean Student Association
description: The purpose of EESA is to nurture a sense of community amongst Ethiopian and Eritrean students at Cornell. We aim to represent the Ethiopian and Eritrean culture in a positive image and help define our presence on campus through social and cultural events.

name: European Business Society, Cornell
description: As a member of the Cornell community, Cornell European Business Society is obligated to enrich the academic environment of the University by educating students and raising awareness about European Businesses on campus.

name: Evo-Group
description: Evo-group is a inter-departmental graduate student run organization that unites undergraduate, graduate students, post-docs, and faculty interested in evolutionary biology. We hold monthly seminars in which students, post-docs, and faculty present their research which they are conducting at Cornell. All Cornell community members are welcome to attend these seminars. We also hold annual meetings in which all evo-group members participate in order to prioritize and plan future directions. We additionally host a one day symposium that highlights a particular topic in evolutionary biology and includes local speakers from nearby Universities in addition to speakers from across Cornell departments.

name: F.C CoCo  (Men's Club Soccer)
description:
F.C CoCo is an organization that is based off of a group of peers who initially played in Cornell University intramural soccer league. The organization desires to promote diversity and inclusion on the campus under the shared interest in soccer. Unlike the traditional try-out system that has been operated by multiple club soccer teams at Cornell, FC Coco's try-outs will focus more on the work ethics, passion, and love towards the sport. Students from diverse backgrounds and with any levels of skills and understanding of soccer are welcome to join the organization. Our ultimate goal is to provide every single member a sense of belonging, and go further to provide opportunities to acquire social capitals, such as social connections, friends, and etc on campus.
As a competitive sports club, we will compete with other clubs on campus, soccer clubs at other colleges in state of NY,  and in Fall/Spring Binghamton tournament, which is run by BUKSA (Binghamton University Korean Students Association), and Fall Ithaca 11 v 11 league.

name: Falconry Club at Cornell
description: To gain knowledge of falconry through practice, education, and hands-on experience.

name: Farmers Educational and Co-Operative Union of America: Cornell Student Chapter
Fashion Forward at Cornell University
description:
Fashion Forward is a student-run organization at Cornell University that utilizes fashion to help the local Ithaca community. 

Through outreach programs, clothing drives, and a charity fashion show and silent auction held each winter, the organization aims to help members of the community afford work attire, obtain a creative outlet, and gain the confidence necessary for success — while at the same time allowing Cornell students to give back to the community as they learn and demonstrate design, event management, graphics and advertising, fundraising and finance, and community outreach skills.

name: Fashion Industry Network, Cornell  (formerly Careers in the Fashion Industry)
Film Club at Cornell
description: We make, edit, watch, enjoy, critique, and appreciate films in both the Cornell and global community. We hold club and school-wide film productions, competitions, festivals, and screenings every week. No experience is necessary to join!

name: Filthy/Gorgeous
description: To create a fun and safe social environment for lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer (LGBTQ+) students and straight allies, lead a celebration of sexuality and gender through all manners of expression while educating the public about safe-sex practices and present-day LGBTQ+ issues and concerns. In conjunction with each of our events is a fundraising goal of combating homelessness among LGBTQ+ youth by donating proceeds and funds raised to LGBTQ+-focused homeless shelters in NYC.

name: First Generation Student Union
description: The purpose of this organization is to create a strong community and network for first-generation college students at Cornell.

name: FiSci, Cornell
description: FiSci members will learn about Fiber Science innovations, research, applications, and developments. With newfound awareness and knowledge about the tech side of fashion, FiSci members will enhance preexisting FSAD organizations. Club members will network with a tailored group of alumni connected to fiber science and STEM in business, industries and research institutions. This will bolster student’s confidence as they seek out jobs and internships. Additionally, it will help student envision how they will fit into the working world.

name: Fishing Club, Cornell
description: The Cornell Fishing Club stands to create an extensive network of freshwater, fly, and saltwater fisherman at Cornell. CFC will serve as a resource for fisherman to meet other fisherman, learn new techniques and seasonal opportunities, swap stories, arrange fishing trips, protect and conserve our waters, provide competitive tournament opportunities, and most of all, promote the advancement of the sport.

name: Flexible Theatre Company
description: The purpose of Flexible Theatre Company is to engage students in the creation and performance of diverse and interesting theatrical performances. Students engage in every aspect of theatrical production.

name: Food Science Product Development Club
description: The purpose of this organization is to foster entrepreneurial spirits and creative mindsets among Cornell students who are interested in pursuing a career in new food product development. FSPD will provide training, consulting and resources so that students are well equipped to approach the multi-dimensional aspects of new product innovation.

name: French Society, Cornell
description: The Cornell French Society’s mission is aiming to promote and encourage all aspects of the French language and culture at Cornell. The society organizes various events during the semester such as our famous gatherings, dinners, parties, tastings of French food, movie nights to socialize in a French environment and much more... We would love for you to join us if you are: interested in the French culture, history, politics, food, fashion and much more, meeting and socializing with International students, speaking and practicing your French, looking into doing a study abroad in France, or going to debates listening to talks and various guest speakers.

name: Friends of Farmworkers
description: Friends of Farmworkers was founded to provide consistent ESL instruction to area farmworkers who know little or no English.

name: Funboard Club
description: The Funboard club is dedicated to enabling advanced windsurfers and kiteboarders to sail and ride in a variety of wind conditions.  We maintain equipment suitable for strong wind, lite wind, and no wind.  On no wind days we practice board skills on land and behind boats.  This may include wake surfing, landboard riding, foilboard riding, and electric skateboard riding.  On lighter wind days we will practice windsurf and kite foilboarding.  This is where you fly a windsurf rig above the water on a hydrofoil.  On high wind days, we may ride smaller windsurf boards, hydrofoil on a windsurfer or with a kite depending on conditions.

name: Future Business Leaders of America - Phi Beta Lambda
description:
Future Business Leaders of America – Phi Beta Lambda (“FBLA-PBL” or “PBL”) inspires and prepares students to become business leaders in a global society through relevant career preparation and leadership experiences. The Cornell University chapter specifically aims to improve access to professional development resources and foster a sense of community among underclassmen and upperclassmen from diverse backgrounds and a variety of majors.

PBL’s programs focus on:
Leadership Development: members develop essential soft skills by holding chapter officer positions, networking with accomplished business professionals, and participating in business-focused workshops, seminars, and academic competitions.
Educational Programs: members participate in weekly educational seminars, gain hands-on experience from collaborative projects, receive individualized feedback from experienced members, and enhance their knowledge with world-recognized skills.
Community Service: members work with the March of Dimes, an organization to improve the health of babies by preventing birth defects, premature birth, and infant mortality. Each semester, members will participate in awareness campaigns and fundraisers for the March of Dimes.

name: Games Club at Cornell
description: Low-traffic, on-topic. Email gamers-l-request@cornell.edu with "join" in the subject line. The mailing list is used for updates regarding room reservations, on-campus events that may impact club meetings. Feel free to use it for organizing RPG campaigns, requesting specific games be brought on a given week, or any other reasonably on-topic message.

name: GEEKS - Grads Employing Empathy, Knowledge, & Service
Genetics, Genomics, & Development Graduate Student Association
description: GGD GSA serves to enrich the academic and social environment for the graduate students in the Field of Genetics, Genomics, and Development in the department of Molecular Biology and Genetics.

name: Ghanaians at Cornell
description: Ghanaians at Cornell is an organization that strives to advertise and share the Ghanaian culture to the Cornell and greater Ithaca community. We provide a home away from home for our many students by providing a strong support system which is vital for thriving at Cornell.

name: Global Health Student Advisory Board
description: The GHSAB is a student-led advisory board committed to developing and improving the global health programming available to undergraduate and graduate students on the Cornell campus. We primarily work on building awareness on global and public health issues through partnerships and organized events, and work with the Global Health Program to increase global health presence and resources on campus.

name: Graceful Shadow - the Chinese Cultural Organization at Cornell
description: The purpose of the organization is to preserve, promote, and celebrate Chinese culture. We are going to host events to promote Chinese philosophy, language, music, martial art, and dance. Anyone who is interested in Chinese culture is welcome to join us.

name: Grads Vote, Cornell
description: To register and educate student voters on campus.

name: Graduate and Professional Students Programming Board
Graduate Association of Chemistry
description: To organize social, professional, and outreach events and opportunities for graduate students to network.

name: Graduate Students in Policy Analysis and Management
description: GSPAM aims to provide resources for graduate students in order to facilitate research and prepare for the job market. This will be accomplished through several different programs. First, GSPAM hosts regular seminars that provide students an opportunity to present and gather feedback on their emerging research to fellow students and faculty. Second, GSPAM holds additional meetings and events on topics related to professional development and the job market (ie. practice presentations, networking events, workshops). Lastly, GSPAM holds social events throughout the year to facilitate camaraderie among graduate students and to serve as a support system during graduate school.

name: Graduate Swing Dance Society, Cornell
description: The purpose of the organization is to teach and promote swing dance to Cornell University students and community members. The organization focuses on dances called swing dance – dances danced to swing jazz music –, such as Lindy Hop, East Coast, Charleston and Balboa swing dances.

name: Gymnastics Club, Cornell
description: We are a team of competitive gymnasts that trains weekly in preparation for travel meets and Nationals, a national competition held by NAIGC (National Association of Intercollegiate Gymnastics Clubs) in April that culminates the season.

name: HanChum Korean Traditional Dance Club, Cornell
Handball Club, Cornell  (previously - U.S. Handball Club)
description: The organization is founded with a focus on allowing the United States handball sport to flourish in Cornell University. As this sport is a novel addition to the University, the goal is to promote both the growth of the club and its constituents. Club members are given the opportunity to not only hone their individual athletic skills but also to improve cooperation in team-based environments.

name: Hawaii Club, Cornell
description: The Cornell Hawaii Club is a cultural/social organization whose purpose is two-fold.  First, we are here to welcome new and current students from Hawai'i and provide them with a network of other Hawai'i students in the Cornell and Ithaca areas. Second, we share the Hawaiian culture with the Cornell and Ithaca communities. The Hawaii club completes these tasks through various events: spam musubi making nights, BBQ's, winter clothes shopping trips, and in the spring we put on a Lu'au! The club is not exclusive to students from Hawaii; we include anyone who is interested in our beautiful state and wants to be included in the fun and networking.

name: Health International, Cornell
description: Cornell Health International (CHI) is a student-run organization that works to enhance knowledge and raise awareness of current global health issues as well as local issues in the Ithaca community. These goals are accomplished through initiatives that seek to promote free exchange of ideas within frameworks of weekly presentations, round table discussions, on-campus activism, and active engagement with the Ithaca community.

name: Healthy Futures: Graduate Chapter, Cornell University
Hellenic Students Association
description: To share and learn about Greek culture, history, and language.

name: Her Campus at Cornell
description: The purpose of the organization is to provide an online lifestyle publication for female college to be educated on issues related to their lives.

name: Historical Linguistics Research Organization, Cornell
description: The purpose of CHLR is to provide an environment for students, faculty, and staff to explore research and topics in the sub-field of historical linguistics, present their own research, invite speakers from outside the university.

name: History of Architecture and Urbanism Society
Horological Investment Club at Cornell
description: To learn about the watch industry, investment potential in timepieces, and opportunities for engagement in the field.

name: HOTEL - American Hotel and Lodging Association Student Chapter at Cornell University
HOTEL - Club Managers Association of America, Cornell Chapter
HOTEL - Hospitality Sales and Marketing Association International
Hotel - National Restaurant Association, Cornell University (formerly Epicurean Society)
HOTEL - National Society of Minorities in Hospitality
HOTEL - SHA Female Leadership in Hospitality
HOTEL - SHA Hospitality Financial & Technology Professionals
HOTEL - SHA Hotelie Entrepreneurs
description: “To provide students with resources and opportunities to explore the entrepreneurial journey and spark their own entrepreneurial spirits.”

name: Impact Dance Troupe
description: Impact Dance Troupe is Cornell University's oldest dance troupe offering choreography and performance opportunities in ballet, modern, jazz, contemporary, hip-hop, tap, and more!  Each semester, members perform original choreography in Impact shows as well as a variety of benefit shows in collaboration with other campus organizations.  We are one of the only groups to have no dues, fees, or costs, and are an equal opportunity, student-run group.

name: India Association, Cornell University
description: We aim to foster an environment of comfort and camaraderie among International students in Cornell’s Graduate and Professional schools, with a focus on students of Indian origin. Also, we strive to spread awareness and celebrate Indian culture in all its vivid glory.

name: Indonesian Association, Cornell
description: The Cornell Indonesian Association aims to serve as a second home for the Indonesian community at Cornell University.

name: Information Science Graduate Student Association
description: The ISGSA promotes professionalization and socialization for graduate students in the department of Information Science.

name: Information Science Student Association - Cornell University
Inter-Cooperative Union
description: The Inter-Cooperative Union is designed to promote collaboration across the cooperative houses on Cornell's campus. The goal of this organization is to allow for communication and support between the houses, as well as to create a setting for dialogue regarding various topics including but not limited to, house management issues, coop-university relations, and overall embodiment of the cooperative spirit. Meetings will discuss topics such as trainings for managing cooperative living, and possible expansion of cooperative living on campus to include more students and houses.

name: Interdisciplinary Semantics Research Organization, Cornell
description: The Cornell Interdisciplinary Semantics Research Organization (CISRO or the Semantics Group) welcomes all students, faculty, and staff who have an interest in semantics from any discipline. While classes are in session we hold weekly meetings where we discuss external semantics research, present and workshop our own semantics research, and occasionally host guest lectures. Our primary objective is to create an encouraging and productive space for discussion, collaboration, and learning--no previous background in semantics is necessary.

name: Interfaith Council, Cornell
description: The Cornell Interfaith Council seeks to promote interfaith dialogue and support religious life on campus, while encouraging shared understanding and celebration of our differences.

name: Into the Streets
description: Into The Streets (ITS) is a student-run program of the Cornell Public Service Center that focuses on promoting social responsibility and commitment to public service among college students. This two-day service experience brings together hundreds of students as Cornell’s largest days of service. This year, as we celebrate the 28th anniversary of Into The Streets, students will continue to learn about the surrounding community and gain experience in public service. The event benefits the community by responding to the needs of local non-profits for volunteers. A wide variety of service projects are organized and each is provided with a team of students. Every team is coordinated and supervised by a student Team Leader. Projects range and may involve demolition, painting, or education, among other things. It is a great way to get out into the local community and meet new people!

name: Invest in China Society, Cornell
description: The purpose o

name: Islamic Alliance for Justice
description: IAJ is a secular student organization that aims to raise awareness and coordinate effective response to local, national, and global issues of social, economic and political justice. The Alliance engages in informational outreach activities as well as advocacy and discourse. This club intends to both provide a way for students interested in the Muslim world to become active in the political realm and to raise awareness of issues of injustice across campus and around the globe.

name: Ivy League Data Analytics Conference Committee
description: Ivy League Data Analytics Conference Committee aims to promote the power of data analytics across a multitude of different fields ranging from Computer Science to biology. One of the primary ways we do so is by coordinating with other institutions of higher education, specifically, Ivy League Universities, to host an annual conference at Cornell University, that brings together students who share a common interest in data analytics and provide them with a platform to gain real-life insights into the industry and get hands-on experience in this field. In addition, to promote and enhance a Data Analytics culture on Cornell campus, the club organizes a series of workshops, guest speaker events from professionals, and fireside chats throughout the semester.

name: Japanese Graduate Students and Scholars Association
JDC@CORNELL
description: JDC@CORNELL is a public service organization that raises money and awareness for the Joint Distribution Committee (also referred to as The Joint). The JDC is the world's leading humanitarian and aid organization that is associated with, but not limited to, Jewish communities around the globe. The JDC is active in around 70 countries and works to alleviate hunger and hardship, rescue people in danger, and help overcome the social challenges or its most vulnerable citizens. The JDC also provides high-impact disaster relief and long-term development assistance worldwide. The JDC@CORNELL is a satellite of this organization, and a perfect way to involve students in their outstanding efforts. A select number of students will receive a once in a lifetime experience of being able to travel internationally to experience what the JDC does abroad.

name: Jewish Studies Club, Cornell
description: The purpose of The Cornell Jewish Studies Club (CJCS) is to create an environment where students from any study, culture or background are able to discuss the Jewish culture, religion and history. Our meetings will incite discussion and learning about Jewish studies. Activities include guest speakers, lectures by upperclassmen and professors, movie showings and discussions, potential trips, and more.

name: JGSM - Alternative, Private, & Hedged Assets (ALPHA) Club
JGSM - Australia and New Zealand Club
JGSM - Health Care Club  (previously - Healthcare & Biotech)
JGSM - High Yield Restructuring Club (previous - Restructuring and Turnaround Club)
JGSM - Hispanic American Business Leaders Association
JGSM - Johnson Food, Beverage, and Agribusiness Club
JGSM - Latin American Business Association (LABA)(Previously -Latino Business Students Association)
JGSM - Outdoor Ventures Club (previously - Adventure Climbing and Exploration)
Juggling Club
description: To provide a forum for those interested in juggling and other circus arts.

name: Kedma
description: Kedma is the Orthodox organization at Cornell that provides for the religious and social needs of Orthodox Jews. Kedma is dedicated to upholding Orthodox values and maintaining a comfortable atmosphere for Orthodox students. By working with other student organizations, Kedma provides focused, well resourced programs and events for Orthodox students, as well as for the Cornell community at large. Kedma oversees the Orthodox prayer services held three times a day on campus. Kedma also maintains the Eruv at Cornell, which allows Jewish students on campus to carry on the Sabbath.

name: Kehilat Shevach: Cornell's Traditional Egalitarian Community
Kidney Disease Screening and Awareness Program
Kiteboarding Club at Cornell
description: To promote kiteboarding in a safe and affordable manner, while protecting the natural environment and advocating for positive social change.  We aim to make kiting accessible to the Cornell Community.

name: Knit With Care
description: The purpose of this organizations is to use the healing powers of knitting and crocheting to help the Cornell and Ithaca community.

name: Lady Bears Volleyball at Cornell University
Language Expansion Program (formerly Language Pairing Program)
Lasting Learning
description: To educate elementary-aged students on subjects such as: environmental science, nutrition, arts, and humanities.

name: Latin Roots
description: To share Latin culture with the wider Ithaca and Cornell community through various forms of Latin dance, including but not limited to salsa, bachata, merengue, and cha cha cha.

name: Latino Christian Community (Previously -Latino Bible Study)
description: Develop a Christian Latino community that supports each other spiritually and emotionally, and strengthen each other through prayers, service, knowledge of God’s Word, love, and faith. All Spanish speaking and non-Spanish speaking students are welcome!

name: LAW - Alternative Dispute Resolution Society
description: The purpose of this organization is to expose the Cornell community to the benefits, skills, and techniques of various alternatives to litigation for resolving disputes, and to support and promote the use of such techniques within the law school, the legal community, and the community at large.

name: LAW - American Constitution Society, Cornell Law School Student Chapter
LAW - Asian Pacific American Law Student Association
LAW - Association of Law & Economics, Cornell
description: Promote the study of law and economics; hold various speaker events and social programs open to the Cornell community.

name: LAW - Black Law Students Association
description: The Black Law Students Association is a professional, nationally-affiliated organization of Black law students dedicated to improving opportunities in legal education. The Cornell chapter actively involves itself in a wide variety of professional, academic, political, cultural, social, and educational activities. BLSA also sponsors various social activities with other law school and non-law school organizations.

name: LAW - BRICS Law Collective
description: The BRICS Law Collective is an association of Cornell Law School students and alumni, aimed at fostering collaboration between lawyers from the BRICS block of nations and their international colleagues.

name: LAW - Briggs Society of International Law
description:
Cornell Law’s Briggs Society of International Law, formally known as the Herbert W. Briggs Society of International Law, is named in honor of Cornell University and Cornell Law professor Herbert W. Briggs. Mr. Briggs was a distinguished editor, lawyer, scholar, and educator in the international legal community.

As an organization, we promote student awareness and interest in current and developing issues within the international and comparative legal field. The Briggs society works to hold events, such as guest speakers, to discuss specific events with international legal implications, help coordinate international moot court competitions, and introduce students to possible careers concerning international law.

name: LAW - California Law Student Association
description: CaLSA is a Cornell law student organization that provides support to students from California and those that want to work or establish a connection in California.  CaLSA uses existing ties to California through alumni and other connections to provide substantive information regarding internships, fellowships, clerkships, Summer Associate positions, and the California state bar exam. CaLSA is open to all individuals seeking a connection to California. Our purpose is to provide the necessary resources and framework to assist CaLSA members achieve the necessary means to succeed in the legal profession.

name: LAW - Environmental Law Society
description: The Environmental Law Society (ELS) is an independent student organization at Cornell Law School. ELS promotes interest in and awareness of environmental law at Cornell University.

name: LAW - If/When/How: Lawyering for Reproductive Justice
description: The realization of reproductive justice: when all people can exercise the rights and access the resources they need to thrive and to decide whether, when, and how to have and parent children with dignity, free from discrimination, coercion, or violence.

name: LAW - Intellectual Property and Technology Students Association
description: IPTSA's purpose is to provide the law school community with outlets, both academic and social, to pursue interests in Intellectual Property, including Patent Law, Copyright Law, Trademark Law, and Technology Transfer Law, via specific events.

name: LAW - International Arbitration Society, Cornell
description: Cornell International Arbitration Society shall provide a forum for the scholarly analysis and discussion of international commercial and investment arbitration, their legal problems and developments.

name: LAW - Journal of Law and Public Policy
LAW - Lambda Law
description: The purpose of Lambda Law Association is to provide programming on LGBTQIA+ legal issues and advocacy and to serve as a welcoming community for LGBTQIA+ law students.

name: LAW - Latino American Law Student Association
description:
The purpose of LALSA shall be to utilize the collective resources of the members to:

-   Articulate and promote the academic and professional needs and goals of Latino law students
-   Foster and encourage professional competence
-   Focus on the relationship of the Latino law student and attorney to the American legal structure 
-   Instill in the Latino law student and attorney a greater awareness of and commitment to the needs of the Latino community
-   Influence the legal community to bring about meaningful change to meet the needs of the Latino community
-   Preserve and promote awareness of Latino culture and unity among Latino groups
-   Do all things necessary and appropriate to accomplish these purposes.

name: LAW - Law School Indoor Soccer Club
description: organizes several indoor soccer teams for a league in Lansing

name: LAW - Law School Veterans Society, Cornell
description: Cornell Law Veterans Association (CLVA) is an organization for law students with (1) current or prior military service (including for the US or for other countries), (2) family members and/or friends with current or prior military service, (3) an interest in law related to military affairs, veterans affairs, and international law, and/or (4) an interest in a career as a JAG officer, Dept. of Veterans Affairs attorney, or other veteran-related law practice.

name: LAW - Law Second Amendment Club, Cornell
description: CL2AC’s purpose is to promote the preservation of 2nd Amendment Rights, foster intelligent debate about firearms laws, promote better education about firearms, and improve members' shooting skills.

name: LAW - Legal Information Institute Supreme Court Bulletin
LAW - LLM Association
description: The purpose of the LLM Association is to represent the LLM student body at Cornell University Law School.  The LLMA holds scholarly and social student events.

name: LAW Œ National Security Law and Policy Society
LAW - Native American Law Student Association
LAW - Public Interest Law Union
description: Cornell Law School's Public Interest Law Union offers opportunities for students interested in a public interest legal career to explore the diversity of career options available to them. The group hosts public interest speaker events, provides volunteer service opportunities for members of the law school, and helps raise funds for grants for law students working in a Public Interest job in the summer.

name: LAW - Society of Wine and Jurisprudence
description: To educate members and the broader community about relevant (primarily legal) issues that impact the production, distribution, and consumption of wine. In keeping with that goal and our broader mission, we also seek to engage our members in professional development and etiquette.

name: LAW - South Asian Law Students Association
LAW - Sports and Entertainment Law Society
LAW - Student Animal Legal Defense Fund
LAW - Tax Law Association, Cornell
description: Promote the study of tax law

name: LAW - The Louis D. Brandeis Center For Human Rights Under Law
LAW - Video Game Law Association
description: To promote awareness and knowledge of legal issues in the video game/interactive entertainment industry and provide resources to those wishing to enter the industry. We will do this by notifying members of competitions, scholarships, and job opportunities in the field. We will also invite speakers to lecture on key issues in the field.

name: LAW - Women's Law Coalition
description: The Women's Law Coalition promotes women in the law through mentorship programs, speakers, networking events, and professional panels.

name: LIFT Mentoring Program
description: Our mission is simple: uplift aspiring Cornell Engineers at all stages of their undergraduate careers. We see engaged, peer-to-peer mentorship as a powerful way to combat systemic and personal factors that often discourage students, especially those from historically underrepresented groups in STEM, from obtaining engineering degrees from Cornell. LIFT not only aims to enrich peer-led resources both at the micro-level and at the macro-level.  We work to provide mentorship and advising opportunities that transcend major, gender, and social identity, as well as post-graduate ambitions.
