Through the creation of an online Q&A platform, we will provide students with a convenient platform for obtaining honest, immediate, and individualized advice from fellow classmates. Our ultimate goal is to broaden the pool of peer mentors made available to engineering students from all walks of campus.

name: Lifters, Cornell University
description: CU Lifters are dedicated community service participants who assist and engage in service projects on Cornell's campus and the Ithaca communities.

name: Linguistics, Computers, and Friends, Cornell
description: The purpose of our organization is to discuss current topics in both computational linguistics and natural language processing. Our organization also serves as a venue for members to discuss and receive feedback on their current research projects.

name: LINK Men's Alliance, The
description: To address the current and historic desire to allow minority men to develop and actively exercise their leadership skills, as well as provide mutual support in dealing with the unique pressures experienced by men of color at Cornell University.

name: Lion Dance, Cornell
description: The purpose of Cornell Lion Dance is to both keep alive the tradition of Lion Dancing as well as enrich the culture of both the campus and the greater Ithaca community.

name: Logos: The Undergraduate Philosophy Journal & Club
Magic the Gathering Club, Cornell
description: The Cornell Magic the Gathering Club is a community built around the collectible trading card game Magic: the Gathering, connecting players and hosting tournaments and casual events.

name: Mainland China Students Association
description: Mainland China Students Association works to provide a network and community for Cornell students who are interested in Mainland Chinese affairs. We hold events to foster cultural enrichment for both MCSA members and the greater Cornell community. Examples include Taste of China, Cultural Show, Chinese New Year Gala, karaoke, movie night, etc. MCSA also strives to hold strong relationships with other organizations on campus with the goal of promoting unity at Cornell. MCSA is committed to bringing the best cultural experience for all those interested.

name: Make Your Mark - Urban Stylized Lettering at Cornell
description: We hold weekly meetings where group study of existing work is deconstructed, cultural history is explored, and proficiency in Writing styles is developed. Guidance is provided by other group members and occasional professionally guided sessions with expert practitioners. Occasional group study and research will be conducted with historical artifacts through the Cornell Hip Hop Collection - a division of the Rare and Manuscript Collection at Cornell Libraries.

name: Malott Hall Football Club
description: Malott Hall FC is an amateur soccer club aiming to provided informal soccer games, trainings and matches, for soccer players or aspiring soccer players of the graduate and professional stripes, primarily, hailing from Malott Hall.

name: Mapping Society at Cornell
description: The purpose of MSC is to grant students opportunities to engage in mapping and related geospatial activities that address challenges at local, national, and global scales. Students will create, analyze, and share open data and learn to use open source software in this process.

name: Marginalia: the Cornell Undergraduate Poetry Review
Materials Society, Cornell
description:
The Cornell Materials Society represents the university’s undergraduate chapter of The Materials Research Society (MRS), The Materials Information Society (ASM), The Minerals, Metals, and Materials Society (TMS), and American Ceramics Society (ACerS). We partner with Materials Advantage to bring students to professional organizations (ACeRS, TMS, ASM, and AIST) at an affordable price.

CMS is a student-run organization devoted to unity of MS&E majors and others interested in the fields of nanotechnology, biomedical engineering, semiconductors, polymers, ceramics, glasses, and metals.

This organization provides leadership and networking opportunities to its members and helps in advancing their careers and promoting their recognition. CMS also participates in community service events to increase interest in engineering, science, and mathematics among today’s youth.

name: Media & Entertainment, Cornell (previously Global Film Studio)
Men of Color Council
description: The purpose of this organization is focused largely around planning and formulating a cohesive network for supporting the overall development of men of color at Cornell University. The objectives of the MOCC shall be: to empower men via academia, leadership, and professional development; assist with the recruitment, retention, and advancement of men of color; provide mentorship to men of color; identify and cultivate future leaders.

name: Men's Club Basketball
description: To provide students with a fun and competitive environment to play basketball, and compete against local and national competition.

name: Men's Club Lacrosse, Cornell
description: As with any competitive sports event, the purpose of our playing organized games is to compete against other teams who share our similar interests in playing the game of lacrosse at a competitive level, and in an enjoyable environment

name: Men's Club Volleyball, Cornell
description: Cornell Men's Club Volleyball is dedicated to playing competitive volleyball in a fun and engaging environment. As part of the Eastern Intercollegiate Volleyball Association (EIVA) we play at least 3 weekend tournaments per semester, capped off by the national tournament hosted by NCVF. Our conference includes Syracuse, Buffalo, Binghamton, Army, RIT, Cortland, and Brockport. If you love playing volleyball, this is the closest to varsity Cornell has to offer. Contact us or find us playing on the beautiful beaches of North Campus. See you at tryouts in early September!

name: Men's Ice Hockey Practice Squad, Cornell
Micronesia Area Service and Development Association
description: To provide quality consulting and community services to organizations in the Micronesia Area

name: Middle Eastern and Mediterranean Ensemble, Cornell
Minorities in Agriculture Natural Resources and Related Sciences
Minority Animal Science Students
description: The primary focus of MASS (Minority Animal Science Students) is to support underrepresented minority students in the field of animal science. This organization understands the continuous struggle of minorities pursuing a future in animal studies, including lack of representation in the field. It shall be the goal of MASS to consciously support these students in the animal science division of undergraduate studies at Cornell University and encourage their success.

name: Minority Business Student Association
description: The purpose of the MBSA is to provide minority scholars at the undergraduate level with the tools and resources for pursuing professional and business ventures. We stay true to our mission by hosting company information sessions, professional development workshops, community service activities, networking sessions and co-sponsoring events and programs with various Cornell organizations. MBSA will assist undergraduate students from all seven colleges at Cornell University in this capacity.

name: Monthly Methods Meetings
description:
To create a safe learning environment for graduate students in the Food Science and Technology department to practice teaching a scientific method to their peers. The club's out reach will occur once a semester where presentations are recorded and uploaded to Youtube to promote scientific outreach, not only to other students looking for a explanation of the method but also to any person interested in the method. 

The videos will not be monetized

name: Mortar Board Der Hexenkreis Senior Honor Society
MOSAIC: For Same Gender Loving People of Color and Allies
Multicultural Academic Council
description: The purpose of our organization is to support diverse graduate students who are historically underrepresented in academia. Our various programs aim to foster a graduate culture of care and support in this academically rigorous environment.

name: Multicultural Concert Funding and Advisory Board
Mundial FC Mens Club Soccer, Cornell
Musical Undergraduates Initiative for Children Veterans and the Sick
Muslim Graduate Students Association
description: The Muslim Graduate Student Association is a community for graduate and professional Muslim students at Cornell. MGSA creates a space for students from various disciplines and programs to learn from each other. MGSA is also open to the Cornell graduate community to educate others about Muslim life, cultures, and social issues.

name: NAI ER XUE SHE (CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY AND CONFUCIANISM CLUB)
description: NAI ER XUE SHE aims to provide a platform for the students who are interested in Chinese culture to discuss and study Chinese culture and arts, especially in calligraphy and confucianism. Chinese calligraphy instructors are available.

name: National Society of Leadership annd Success
Native American and Indigenous Students At Cornell
Naval Reserve Officer Training Corps, Cornell
NEO@CU  -  (Northeast Ohio at Cornell University)
description: NEO@CU is a group established to form, maintain, and enhance relationships between students, alumni, faculty, and staff who have connections to the Greater Cleveland Metropolitan Area and Northeast Ohio region.

name: Network of Enlightened Women - Cornell University Chapter
Neurobiology and Behavior Graduate Student Society
description: The purpose of the NBBGSS is to facilitate communication between the graduate students and the faculty in the field of NBB at Cornell. Our goals include disseminating important information to graduate students and acting as a formal voice for graduate students within the workings of the department. Additionally, the NBBGSS fosters community among graduate students in the field by organizing social events and discussion forums.

name: New York Water Environment Association Student Chapter at Cornell
description:
We are a student organization for those interested in Protecting Water Resources, Water Quality, Public Health, Sustainability, Ecology, and/or the Environment. We offer student members with opportunities like:
•  Meeting Potential Employers!  
•  Getting Reduced Membership and Meeting Registration
•  Keeping Current on Technical & Regulatory Development   
•  Networking with Environmental Professionals  
•  Scholarship Opportunities  
•  Professional Recognition & Development  
•  Presenting Papers at Chapter & Statewide Meetings  
•  Becoming an author for the NYWEA Clearwaters magazine
•  Learning and practicing leadership roles by becoming actively involved in the organization  
•  Making a contribution to more effective water environment activities

name: Nigerian Students Association
description: The purpose of the Nigerian Students Association is to foster cultural unity and understanding among the Nigerian community at Cornell. We hope to provide a forum that will celebrate the diversity embodied in Nigeria through cultural events, educational seminars, and community outreach programs, as well as sharing the culture not only with Nigerian students, but with the Cornell community at large.

name: NOMAS: Cornell
description:
To enable the further exploration of the study of architecture for the mutual
advancement of the community and student body. Connect with professionals in the discipline and all matters relative to the curriculum in order to expose members to the many aspects of the profession. Work towards an unbiased, tolerant, sensitive, and welcoming professional community. To educate regarding the importance of, and working towards, the preservation of the environment and culture.

name: Open Orchestra, Cornell
description: To create a non-competitive, less demanding community for Cornell students who play string instruments, with a common performance goal.

name: Opera Society, Cornell
description: We aspire to contribute to opera education at Cornell and to provide a space where students can come together and share their passion for opera through performance and operatic discourse.

name: Organization for Labor Action, Cornell  (Previously - Students Against Sweatshop)
Origami Club
description: Practice the ancient art of origami through folding, teaching, and discussion.

name: Out in Science Technology Engineering and Mathematics @ Cornell
Pakistan Society, Cornell
description: To provide a space for graduate students from Pakistan to interact with each other, meet policy/business professionals, network and exchange ideas.

name: Pakistani Students Association
description: To represent Pakistan and Pakistani students and to promote knowledge and understanding of Pakistani culture on-campus.

name: Pandaemonium Germanicum
description:
1.	To foster the social and intellectual environment of graduate students in the Department of German Studies.
2.	To represent the interests and concerns of graduate students in the Department of German Studies.
3.	To participate in the social and intellectual life of the university.
4.	To promote a critical understanding of German Studies.
5.	To address and support the professional development of future academics in the discipline of German Studies.

name: Partners In Health | Engage at Cornell University
PATCH - Pre-professional Association Towards Careers in Health
PhD Students at Cornell Tech
description: PhD Students at Cornell Tech (PACT) is a student organization dedicated to matters concerning the community of PhD students at the Cornell Tech campus in New York City. The organization serves to address issues of common concern within the community and voice those issues to Cornell University and Cornell Tech administration. PACT also serves to facilitate community events, including those both academic and social.

name: Phenomenon Step Club
description: Phenomenon Step Team's purpose is to diffuse the culture of South African Gum Boot dance in an American context through stepping performances. It is also the only non-greek step team on Cornell University's campus.

name: Phi Delta Epsilon International Medical Fraternity
Phi Gamma Nu Professional Business Fraternity
Phi Sigma Pi National Honors Fraternity- Beta Nu Chapter
Philip Payton Society for Minority Real Estate Professionals
description: To encourage a space where minority students interested in careers related to the built environment (real estate, architecture, urban planning & construction) can convene and support each other as they pursue their students in these traditionally non-diverse fields.

name: Philosophy, Leadership, Advocacy, and Training Organization
description: PLATO is the Sage School of Philosophy Field Organization. We are committed to providing support for incoming and current graduate students. In particular, we aim to enhance the graduate school experience by facilitating communication among students and between students and faculty. We also work to increase the number of opportunities aimed at the following: improving teaching, research, and leadership skills, as well as enhancing support for non-academic career goals.

name: Pi Sigma Alpha, Political Science Honor Society
Piano Society, Cornell
description: Cornell Piano Society provides a community for pianists and piano fans in the Cornell community of all ages, abilities, and interests. We provide member-to-member lessons to help beginners sharpen their skills and to help intermediate students keep up with their practicing and performing. We hold formal and informal concerts throughout the year. We host various social events to foster a community of people on campus who love piano. We collaborate with other organizations on campus who are looking for pianists. We connect our members with resources on campus including university lessons, master classes, performance opportunities, visiting musicians, and more.

name: Planned Parenthood Generation Action (previously Vox: Voices for Planned Parenthoood)
Plant Biology Graduate Student Association
description:
Coagulation.
Community to inspire.
Meeting of the minds.

name: Pre-Health Mentorship Program
description: Pre-Health Mentorship Program, is a mentorship program open to all pre-health students. Freshman/Sophomore mentees will be matched with Junior/Senior based on common interests. Mentors will provide mentees with advice on curriculum requirements, HCEC requirements, clinical experiences, research, summer experiences, medical school applications, and gap years. Students of diverse academic backgrounds will be able to share their interests in the healthcare field, and their path to reaching their goals.

name: Pre-Med Minorities Mentorship Program
description: The mission of PreM3 is to encourage, advise, support and retain underrepresented ethnic minority undergraduates in the pre-med track at Cornell University by providing one-on one peer mentorship and guidance through programs that expose participants to the field of medicine.

name: Pre-Professional Health Association, College of A&S
description: This organization aims to familiarize students with the medical professions and application to relevant schools through speakers, student mentors, and volunteer work (i.e. blood drives). We are geared toward the College of Arts and Sciences, addressing issues such as credit requirements, distribution requirements specific to the college, and being pre-health with a non-science major. However, all students are welcome to join.

name: Preservation Studies Student Organization
description:
The Preservation Studies Student Organization (PSSO) was built to facilitate and strengthen the graduate students within the Historic Preservation Planning program at Cornell University. It provides graduate student representation within the Department of City and Regional Planning and Cornell University, while raising awareness with regards to the field of Historic Preservation Planning through social activities, information sharing and building a practical skill set related to the preservation of the built environment. The organization celebrates history and aims to build a community where students from a variety of backgrounds and interests are brought together by their common interest in historic preservation. 


We provide academic, social and professional support and services to those students in historic preservation and cultural resources and meet approximately once a month to discuss activities and issues facing the preservation community. Furthermore, we provide information for the students and faculty of the school of Architecture, Art and Planning through yearly lecture series and conferences.

Efforts are made to coordinate educational opportunities with the Organization of Cornell Planners (OCP) and with the Historic Preservation Planning Alumni organization (HPPA).

name: Pre-Student Osteopathic Medical Association
description: To promote Osteopathic medicine, increase the number of applicants to Osteopathic medical schools, support aspiring Osteopathic physicians at all levels of education, and continue the proud legacy of Osteopathic Medicine.

name: Prison Reform and Education Project (PREP)   (Previously- Redemption Project)
Pro Football Society, Cornell
description: The purpose of the Society is to both foster and augment the members’ passion for and love of the game of football. In addition, the Society intends to act as a medium through which passionate fans can make predictions, have debates, and hold discussions. It is intended that the Society will create a fun, engaging, and didactic environment for all fans of professional football at Cornell.

name: Professional Fraternity Council
description: The purpose of this council is to maintain the system of PFOs, connect the PFOs in their individual points of action, support the recruitment of new members to PFOs, build relationships and networks between its PFO members, support mutual efforts of fundraising by the PFOs, and provide professional opportunities to the members of the PFOs, general student body, and community at large.

name: Prospect of Whitby
description: The purpose of the Prospect of Whitby is a communal living environment of supportive Cornell students.

name: Psi Chi the International Honors Society in Psychology
Psychological Society Yielding Cornell Health Practitioners
description: PSYCH is a group established to guide, support and encourage students interested in psychology and health and to provide them with tools, support and resources necessary to pursue professional and academic success. P.S.Y.C.H looks to offer its members professional development activities, mentoring opportunities and career placement services.

name: Queer Political Action Committee
description: QPAC is the political action arm for all queer students on campus.

name: Quidditch, Cornell
description: Quidditch has grown into legitimate and challenging competitive sport around the country. Our team competes against nearby schools and attends local tournaments.

name: Quiz Bowl Club, Cornell
description: The Quiz Bowl Club provides an enjoyable, supplementary learning experience for Cornellians through the collective playing of quizbowl questions. We are primarily recreational, though the game is inherently competitive. We represent Cornell at quizbowl tournaments held at universities across the Northeast several times per semester, and usually send one or two teams to national competitions. For more information on college quizbowl, you can check out https://acf-quizbowl.com/. No prior experience is necessary to enjoy the game.

name: Quodlibet
description: To provide a lively forum for all those interested in all things medieval on campus.  To organize a series of lectures to highlight current research topics relating to medieval studies.

name: Rainy Day
description: Rainy Day is the longest running literary magazine on the Cornell University campus, publishing a biannual magazine presenting the finest student literary works to the widest audience possible. We are a cooperative group of editors who critique work through interactive meetings. Our staff members come from myriad backgrounds: Economics, Biology, Philosophy, English and other majors. We have been publishing for 50 years at Cornell and were founded by Professor Kenneth A. McClane who is now W.E.B. Du Bois Professor of Literature Emeritus and who said in our 30th anniversary issue, “Rainy Day might well be the longest-lived student publication in the country.” Rainy Day is a prestigious magazine with a long tradition: in our first year, we published a poem by Richard Price, a now-famous novelist and screenwriter (author of “Clockers”) and published poems by now famed writers Anselm Hollo, James Bertolino, and Thomas Johnson.

name: Reading Rainbow
description: Reading Rainbow seeks to foster dialogue regarding LGBTQ+ issues between people of differing identities through literature. We will read books relating to LGBTQ+ issues and then meet to discuss them.

name: Recreational Tennis Club
description: Our club provides a resource for students to have fun playing tennis outside of a competitive or selective environment. We help students find people to play with or similar skill levels and offer opportunities for beginners to learn and others to improve.

name: Red Studio Cornell
description: The primary mission of Red Studio Cornell is to provide exceptional design service to students and other student organizations on Campus. Simultaneously, it serves as an open platform for people who are interested or proficient in the field of design and art to share their unique experience in their careers.

name: Reserve Tennis Club, Cornell
description: The Cornell Reserve Tennis Club is intended for intermediate and advanced tennis players who want to play regular tennis with a group of similar players. You are a perfect candidate for this club if you A) played tennis regularly in high school, but now find yourself struggling to make time for tennis or find hitting buddies, B) tried out for the Cornell Tennis Club and didn't make it, or C) played tennis casually in the past and want to improve. We practice twice a week and also play several matches against other area colleges each semester Our goal is to create a small, close community of committed tennis players.

name: Residential Student Congress
description: To promote the formation of a community and foster interaction, a sense of unity, and respect for others through social, cultural, and education programming. To serve as representative for the resident of complex and the residential student congress.

name: Rise Dance Group
description: Rise Dance Group aims to extend the opportunity of dance to all Cornell students who seek to continue their passion for dance. Our group is open to many styles and backgrounds, performing routines in contemporary, jazz, ballet, tap, and hip hop based on our dancers' interests. We are a close group of friends who not only enjoy dance but are an involved part of the amazing dance community at Cornell.

name: Risley Kommittee
description: The purpose of Risley Residential College is to promote the creative and performing arts in the Cornell and Ithaca communities. The purpose of Risley Kommittee is to serve as the student-run governing body for Risley Residential College. Kommittee is in the simplest sense, a gathering of the Risley community to discuss upcoming events, funding, building concerns and secret agendas determined by the master of ceremonies: ¡El Presidente for Life. Each Kommittee has a theme, which is usually decided at the previous week’s Kommittee by the higher-ups.Reports are given by each RA, the RHD, ARHD, the Artist in Residence and any other titled Risley members who happen to attend. After the formal reports, the floor is open to anyone (resident of Risley or not) who has a request or concern. If you’re looking to do an event, fund an event or just interested in what’s going on in the place where you live and how to get involved, Kommittee is the place to be!

name: Risley Theatre
description: The purpose of Risley Theatre is to both oversee the operation of Risley Theatre and to produce theatrical production in Risley Theatre. We do this while providing students access to running every aspect of the theatre.

name: Robotics Graduate Student Organization
description: The purpose of this organization is to foster fellowship between labs and members of the Cornell graduate student robotics community and beyond, independent of department affiliation.

name: Rock Climbing Club, Cornell
description: The purpose of our organization is to further develop Cornell's recreational and competitive rock climbing community. Through training, we seek to improve our climbing abilities, compete in official USAC competitions, compete in informal local competitions, and take climbing trips to outdoor locations.

name: Romance Studies Graduate Student Association
description: Romance Studies Graduate Student Association is an organization for graduate students of all levels and statuses within Cornell's department. While Romance Studies houses the sub-departments of Spanish, French, and Italian, the RSGSA will provide leadership and assembly possibilities that seek to enhance unity and shared interests of all language sections in the department. The student association will work closely with the steering committee to develop programming that helps graduates in their academic and professional efforts. The RSGSA also wishes to support the existing efforts of the French Studies program, the Program in European Studies, as well as existing student groups linked to the Romance Studies department, through better organization. We hope the Romance Studies Graduate Student Association will give the department's graduate students the best opportunity to contribute and share scholarly and professional goals.

name: Rugby Sevens, Cornell
description: A competitive rugby 7s club that aims to bring the exciting sport of 7s rugby to the Cornell campus. We have matches both against Ivy League and non-Ivy League opponents.

name: Russian Language Club
description:
To facilitate Russian language learning/retainment through conversation and social events.
To promote appreciation for Russian culture through movie screenings and lectures, accessible to speakers and non-speakers alike.

name: SAGES - Student Association of the Geneva Experiment Station
SALSA PALANTE!
description: Salsa ¡Pa’lante!, established in 2004, is dedicated to enhance the Latin arts community at Cornell and Ithaca through instruction and performance of Salsa choreographies and improvised Rueda de Casino demonstrations.

name: Sangre Taina: The Puerto Rican Students' Association
Santos Soccer Club  (previously, United Men's Club Soccer, Cornell)
Saudi Club
description: Cornell Saudi Club (CSC) celebrates and promotes the Saudi Arabian culture, history, and tradition throughout the Cornell and Ithaca community by organizing and hosting relevant events and activities. CSC also gathers and represents all current and alumni Cornell Saudi students and addresses their needs and concerns.

name: Scare Me at Cornell
description: The purpose of the club is allow people to gain experience and expertise in being able to either recite stories or make them up on the spot. And, if not they do not feel comfortable enough to speak, then they should be able to gain enough courage to eventually be able to do so. It is also designed to be a place where people can feel comfortable talking about their own horrors and express themselves.

name: Scheinman Conflict Resolution Club at Cornell
Scholars in Our Society and Africa
Science & Technology Studies Graduate Student Association
Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers' Alliance
description: The club aims to promote student writing in the sci-fi and fantasy genre. The purpose of the organization is to offer a creative environment where writers with a common interest in sci-fi and fantasy can share, critique, and improve their work. The group will set word count goals, examine members’ writing, and revel in the awesomeness of sci-fi with the occasional movie night.

name: Scientista Foundation Chapter at Cornell University
Semper Fidelis Society
description: The Semper Fi Society's purpose is to train future officers of the Marine Corps. The Semper FI Society will teach members the organization, traditions, values, and roles of the Marine Corps.

name: Service Pups for Merlin's Kids, Cornell
SGI Campus Club
description: Cornell SGI, as a campus arm of SGI-USA, will work for what we refer to as "Kosen-Rufu". In other words, our mission is to help each person believe in, and reveal their innate, unlimited potential as a human being who respects the dignity of all life.

name: Shadows Dance Troupe
description:
Shadows Dance Troupe exists to provide Cornell students with the opportunity to dance and perform, with qualifications including experience, merit, enthusiasm, effort, and personal commitment.
Shadows holds auditions twice a year: at the beginning of the fall semester and at the beginning of the spring semester. We are always looking for strong, talented dancers. If you are interested in auditioning, please look out for information on this page or contact one of our co-chairs!

name: Shake Ultimate
description: To field a strong ultimate team that can compete at a regional level while developing the skills and athleticism of all players and to promote a fun and inclusive environment for all.

name: She's the First
description: She’s the First fights for a world where every girl chooses her own future. We team up with local organizations to make sure girls are educated, respected, and heard.

name: Shimtah, Cornell
description: Our mission is to teach, share, and perform traditional Korean folk music within the Cornell and Ithaca community. We hope to promote the traditional musical aspect of Korean culture, and thus contribute to the cultural and ethnic diversity here at Cornell University. We wish to display the passion and skill of those in Shimtah, and in turn, the reasons for our dedication to this form of music. This club also provides opportunity for students of Korean heritage or those interested in Korean culture to form a social network.

name: Shogi Club, Cornell
description: We aim to build a community of students who enjoy playing shogi. We do not care about the skill level of players, so everyone is welcomed. We are a group to have fun with shogi!

name: SiGMA: Sibley Graduates in Mechanical & Aerospace
Sikh Students Association
description:
Purpose and Aims:
1.	The Cornell Sikh Students Association (CSSA) is a multi-purpose organization. It will serve as the voice of Sikh students on campus and allow them the opportunity to practice and express their faith at Cornell.

2.	CSSA will serve as a platform for members, visitors and the greater student and public population to learn about and discuss Sikhi, as well as pioneer public awareness and education regarding (but not limited to) Sikhi’s beliefs, identity, history and the significance of its festivals. More specifically, CSSA will aim to ensure that over time, the majority of Cornell students can comfortably recognize the Sikh identity and are at the least, familiar with its principal values and beliefs.

3.	CSSA will serve as a forum to openly converse about, bring attention and awareness for and brainstorm and implement solutions to any matters representing Sikh interests, including but not limited to Sikhi, Punjab, Sikh politics and issues affecting the Sikh identity.

4.	CSSA will strive to form connections, relationships and conferences with other Sikh organizations on an inter-collegiate, national and international level. We will further strive to create connections with Sikh alumni, professionals, or pioneers in any particular field.

5.	CSSA will work, often in conjunction with other organizations on campus, to promote tolerance, service, inter-faith dialogue and the vision for a common humanity.

6.	The spirit of sewa, or selfless service, will be one of the core values upon which the organization will function.

name: Skateboarding Club, Cornell
description: The Cornell Skateboarding Club aims to organize all members of the Cornell Community who are interested in, already enamored of, or willing to learn about or participate in the sport of skateboarding. We are a cohesive, active, and vibrant community of skateboarders and skateboarding enthusiasts. We aim to provide equipment and obstacles for seasoned and beginning skateboarders alike. We visit off-campus skateboarding locales in the Ithaca area and beyond. We hope to educate folks who want to get into skateboarding but don't know how. One main goal is to film, edit, and produce a video showcasing the vast array of skateboarding talent that Cornell has to offer.

name: Ski and Snowboard Club, Cornell
description: To promote recreational involvement in winter sports on campus through trips to local mountains, movie screenings and other events related to winter sports.

name: Smiles For Students
description: To enhance oral hygiene and health in the Ithaca area via fundraising and service events.

name: Snee Graduate Organization
description: The mission of the Snee Graduate Organization is to enhance the professional and social interaction between graduate students in the fields of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences. The organization also serves as a medium for communication between the graduate student body and the faculty of the Earth and Atmospheric Sciences at Cornell University.

name: Snodgrass and Wigglesworth, Cornell Undergraduate Entomology Club
Social Enterprise at Cornell
description:
SEC empowers students to build a career in social and environmental impact. We believe that every student brings a crucial perspective that can shape a brighter tomorrow, and keep our resources and events open to all! We hope to serve as a catalyst in three respects:

Education. SEC provides educational resources so that students in a variety of professional pursuits can learn about impact investment, social consulting, social entrepreneurship, and social design.

Innovation. SEC fosters creativity and supports innovative solutions to social and environmental problems through ideathons, workshops, competitions, and other events.

Community. Most importantly, SEC creates community by providing opportunities for students to meet others in our university’s diverse student body and learn from a collective pool of knowledge.

name: Social Enterprise Group at Cornell (Social Venture Club, Cornell )
Sociedad de Debate en Espaol de Cornell
Society for Advancement of Chicanos/Hispanics and Native Americans in Science at Cornell
Society for Asian American Graduate Affairs
description: The organization aims to be a community for graduate and professional students that either self-identify as Asian/Asian American or are interested in topics relating to the Asian/Asian American experience. We provide members the opportunity to socialize with others, share academic and professional advice, and discuss issues of race, ethnicity, politics, and culture as they pertain to Asians/Asian Americans. Our activities include invited lectures, discussions, film screenings, and collaborations with other similar groups on campus and networking events.

name: Society for Experimental Writers
description: The purpose of Society for Experimental Writers (S.E.W.) is to promote the craft of creative writing among graduate students who want to disseminate their creative writing projects in a professional manner. Our aim is to create a diverse and active community of writers. S.E.W. has a plethora of writers from diverse backgrounds that specialize in romance languages. Writing in these languages is not only promoted but also encouraged. Disseminating works in languages other than English is unique to our creative writing group.

name: Society for Human Resource Management, Cornell
description: Cornell SHRM is the Cornell student chapter of the Society for Human Resource Management. The Society for Human Resource Management (SHRM) is the world’s largest association devoted to human resource management. Representing more than 250,000 members in over 140 countries, the Society serves the needs of HR professionals and advances the interests of the HR profession. Founded in 1948, SHRM has more than 575 affiliated chapters within the United States and subsidiary offices in China and India.

name: Society for the Promotion of Indian Classical Music And Culture Amongst Youth
description: It seeks to foster the exchange of traditional Indian values and to generate awareness of the cultural traditions and heritage of India, namely through music and dance. In order to achieve its goals, SPICMACAY organizes concerts, lectures, demonstrations, informal discussions, and seminars. These are hosted by local chapters of the organization.

name: Soil and Crop Sciences Graduate Student Association
description: The goals of this organization are to promote community and professional development within the field of Soil and Crop Sciences and to encourage interactions among students, faculty, and staff.

name: South East Asia Graduate Student Association
description: To bring together graduate students interested in and/or doing research with aerial concentration in South East Asia.

name: Spark Product and Industrial Design Club  (Previously -Prior Product Design Club)
Spikeball Club, Cornell
description: This organization is designed for the dual purpose of introducing new players to the game of Spikeball and connecting experienced players with others of similar skill levels. Even for students who have never heard of or seen Spikeball before, we aim to teach everything we know: the rules, the basics of play, and more advanced moves and tactics when appropriate. For us, Spikeball has provided countless afternoons and evenings of fun and we hope to share that with the rest of the Cornell community!

name: Sport Taekwondo at Cornell
description: We provide Cornell students with the opportunity to learn the martial art of taekwondo and compete in intercollegiate tournaments and other events.

name: Squash Club at Cornell
description: The purpose of the Club is to form a community of squash players at Cornell for both recreational and competitive play. We strike a balance between the pressure and time commitment of varsity squash and the limited recreational play time associated with intramural squash. We play throughout the school year at the Grumman and Belkin courts, where we aim to practice 2 times per week. In addition to practices, we host matches and travel to both club and varsity squash teams.

name: Sri Lankan Students' Association
description: The purpose of this organization is to serve as a community for students of Sri Lankan ethnicity, as well as those interested in Sri Lankan culture. We hope to bring awareness of Sri Lankan culture to the Cornell body.

name: Statistics Club, Cornell
description: The Cornell Statistics Club main objective will be to: (i) supplement and complement statistics education at Cornell by getting teams of statistics and biometry majors involved in data science analysis and statistical consulting for other groups on campus, (ii) host seminars by graduate students and Professors in the subject of statistics, (iii) student-run lessons on important statistical techniques, (iv) get together networking and social events for Statistical Science Majors in the College of Arts & Sciences and Biometry & Statistics Majors in the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, and (v) help interested students learn what Statistics is all about.

name: Student Activities Funding Commission (previously - Student Assembly Finance Commission)
Student Perspectives on Engineering Culture
description: SPEC provides a forum for College of Engineering students to consider and discuss their academic and related mental health experiences among their peers. SPEC conducts research into the history of engineering education to give context to issues related to the modern day realization of engineering curricula at the undergraduate level. SPEC explores actions to advocate for the incorporation of student perspectives in engineering academic policies and practices.

name: Students Against the Sexual Solicitation of Youth
description: Students Against the Sexual Solicitation of Youth (SASSY), a program of Cornell’s Public Service Center, founded in 2007 through a Cornell Alternative Breaks trip since 2003, is committed to raising awareness and transforming public perception of the Commercial Sexual Exploitation of Children (CSEC). SASSY works directly with Girls Educational and Mentoring Services (GEMS), a non-profit agency in New York City, whose mission is to “empower girls and young women, ages 12–24, who have experienced commercial sexual exploitation and domestic trafficking to exit the commercial sex industry and develop to their full potential. GEMS is committed to ending commercial sexual exploitation and domestic trafficking by changing individual lives, transforming public perception, and revolutionizing the systems and policies that impact commercially sexually exploited youth.” SASSY has engaged with the Cornell community while maintaining and strengthening its relationship with and support for GEMS. SASSY has hosted several workshops, discussions, and movie screenings for the Cornell community.

name: Students for Justice in Palestine, Cornell
Students of Color, The Association For
Sustainability Initiative, Cornell
description: An umbrella organization that helps bring together sustainability organizations and sustainable business organizations in order to co-host events, help run yearly Cornell Business Impact Symposium, and support different initiatives related to sustainability.

name: Swim With Your Heart
description:
We raise funds through an annual swim-a-thon, individual campaign directors’ campaigns across the nation and a pool party.

We swim laps, run, walk, roll, float and dedicate our time and dollars.

We thrive in spite of paralysis, amputation, and blindness.

name: Syntax Reading Group
description: This group meets once a week to read and discuss current issues in Syntactic Theory and area studies that are not covered in the formal classes.

name: Take Back the Tap at Cornell
Tang Soo Do at Cornell
description: Tang Soo Do at Cornell seeks to strengthen students by empowering them with the martial art form Tang Soo Do.

name: Tau Beta Pi National Engineering Honor Society
description:
Tau Beta Pi is the only engineering honor society representing the entire engineering profession. It is the nation's second-oldest honor society, founded at Lehigh University in 1885 to mark in a fitting manner those who have conferred honor upon their Alma Mater by distinguished scholarship and exemplary character as students in engineering, or by their attainments as alumni in the field of engineering, and to foster a spirit of liberal culture in engineering colleges.

There are now collegiate chapters at 241 US colleges and universities, 30 active alumni chapters in 15 districts across the country, and a total initiated membership of approximately 540,000.

name: Tech Sports Club, Cornell
description: Bring Cornell Tech Masters students together to play sports

name: Tennis Club, Cornell
description: The Cornell Reserve Tennis Club is intended for intermediate and advanced tennis players who want to play regular tennis with a group of similar players. You are a perfect candidate for this club if you A) played tennis regularly in high school, but now find yourself struggling to make time for tennis or find hitting buddies, B) tried out for the Cornell Tennis Club and didn't make it, or C) played tennis casually in the past and want to improve. We practice twice a week and also play several matches against other area colleges each semester Our goal is to create a small, close community of committed tennis players.

name: Teszia Belly Dance Troupe
description: Teszia Belly Dance Troupe was started at Cornell University in 1996 to provide an outlet for troupe members to join together in celebration of their collective interest in the oriental (belly) dance art form. We encourage troupe members to develop their dance skills by providing instruction and regular practices, as well as performance opportunities, all of which culminate in our annual Spring Shimmy dance show.

name: Thai Association, Cornell
description: CTA brings together all Thai's ranging from freshmen undergraduates to PhD candidates as well as those who express interest in Thai culture. Throughout the year, get-together events forge the bonds between members, and cultural events celebrate Thai culture.

name: Thai Boxing Club
description: Cornell Thai Boxing Club provides members of the Cornell community an opportunity to learn and practice the martial sport of Thai Boxing (Muay Thai). Safety and learning will be our utmost priority, and to that end we have a certified instructor from World Thai Boxing Association, Ajarn Kevin Seaman, guiding us. Since the leaders of the club have taken his class, they will use his teaching to develop proper technique and hone each member’s skills and conditioning. All levels of interest and experience are welcomed and respected. To participate in controlled contact sparring, it must be sanctioned by the instructor and both participants must sign the Waiver and Release Form.

name: The 180
description: The 180 is an annual student-run publication that covers the happenings of the School of Hotel Administration at Cornell University. We aim to provide tangible memories through photos and recollection of moments from all members of the SHA community. We publish a magazine with student quotes and photos once every academic year.

name: The D.R.E.A.M. (Development, Relief, Education for Alien Minors) Team
The First Amendment
description: The premise of The First Amendment will be to provide viewpoints across the entire spectrum on important and divisive topics. We plan to publish bi-monthly (every other month) to start and hope to increase publication frequency from there as we come to understand the process better and gain more contributing members.Freedom of speech remains a complex, fascinating issue and we believe the Cornell student body needs a constructive means of engaging in respectful debate on important and pressing issues.

name: The Grid
description: Its purpose is to provide a creative outlet for design-hungry students at Cornell University. We are the intersection between hospitality and design, collaborating together to learn, practice, and build electronically and physically.

name: The Naked Truth
description: The Naked Truth (TNT) is a student based coalition at Cornell University working to eradicate sexual violence on campus and in the greater Ithaca community. We are dedicated to destigmatizing the conversation around sexual violence and exposing the naked truth of its impact and prevalence in society. TNT will work to create a safe space where victims are empowered and can safely regain their voices. TNT’s goal is to inspire a culture that shifts shame from victims to perpetrators, holds predators accountable and no longer tolerates sexual violence.

name: The Straight Edge Project
description: to deliver elaborate student-lead design proposals for existing spaces on campus, at the conceptual level.

name: Therapy Thru Music
description: To bring musicians with all levels of experience to play for patients in hospitals, nursing homes, or other facilities housing people who are ill.

name: TIPTOE&
description: TIPTOE& is an organization that aims to utilize the provocative design of streetwear fashion to raise awareness on specific social issues. Our name comes from the idea that even a small action such as standing on your tiptoes can allow people to look beyond the fence of ignorance for social issues that are often brushed upon. We first identify a specific social issue that deserves more attention. Then we design, produce, and sell streetwear fashion items that carry a core theme of the issue. Finally, a significant portion of our profits are donated to relevant organizations. Ultimately, TIPTOE& challenges the norm of traditional donation-spending by designing, marketing and selling trendy, high-quality fashionwear to the everyday consumer to participate in a good cause without relying solely on kindness.

name: Track & Field Club
description: The mission of PreM3 is to encourage, advise, support and retain underrepresented ethnic minority undergraduates in the pre-med track at Cornell University by providing one-on one peer mentorship and guidance through programs that expose participants to the field of medicine.

name: Transitioning at Cornell
description: This group was started in the hopes of supporting individuals at Cornell as they transition medically and legally. We hope to provide both community and information to our group members. In this group, we will address current events relevant to the transgender community, discuss legal and medical information on topics such as surgeries, hormones, and name and gender marker changes. We will also have opportunities as a group to hear from both mental and medical health professionals from Cornell Health’s transgender care team.

name: Tropical Biology & Conservation - Graduate Student Association
description: Understanding and conserving tropical species, ecosystems, landscapes and biodiversity is a major challenge facing society today. Furthermore, anthropogenic effects on the tropics and the human factors (social, cultural, political, and economic) driving such effects, add enormous complexity to such an urgent task. In all, tropical biology and conservation involves complex and coupled ecological and social systems. Therefore, in affiliation with the Association for Tropical Biology and Conservation, Cornell’s new Tropical Biology and Conservation – Graduate Student Association (TBC-GSA) brings together graduate students and early career scientists across campus to share their research and efforts, while promoting the links between ecological and social dimensions for conserving tropical biodiversity. Interests of TBC-GSA cover a wide array of basic and applied research topics on tropical biology and conservation, including: structure, dynamics and functioning of tropical ecosystems, anthropogenic effects on tropical biodiversity and ecosystems, social-cultural and political-economic drivers of such effects, and more.

name: TST BOCES Career Skills at Cornell
description:
Career Skills is a career exploration
program at Cornell University designed
to teach vocational-related skills to
students who have an IEP (individual
educational plan). These are students
working towards acquiring a CDOS
(Career Development Occupational
Studies) Commencement Credential or
the SACC.
Collaborating with the Cornell Public
Service Center, Career Skills provides
student exploration of a variety of
realistic career options on the Cornell
campus. Cornell student mentors will
partner with TST BOCES students and
staff to help facilitate this process.

name: Turning Point USA, Cornell
description: The organization’s mission is to identify, educate, train, and organize students to promote the principles of freedom, free markets, and limited government.

name: Ukulele Club, Cornell University
description: Cornell Ukulele Club exists to promote the study and performance of ukulele music. We focus on learning basic techniques and enhancing the skills of the members. We intend to perform and bring ukulele music to the Cornell campus as well as the surrounding Ithaca area.

name: Undergraduate Biomedical Engineering Society at Cornell
Undergraduate Disability Studies Journal
description: The Cornell Undergraduate Disability Studies Journal publishes undergraduate research pertaining to disability studies. The aim of the journal is to promote the work of students exploring disability issues and to give students the opportunity to engage with disability studies research by working on the editorial board.

name: Undergraduate Labor Institute
description: The Undergraduate Labor Institute is a student-run think tank with a focus on labor relations.

name: Undergraduate Veterans Association of Cornell University
Upstate Cornell Connection
description: The Upstate Cornell Connection is a student-run organization that provides undergraduate students considering a pre-health profession with a mentorship opportunity with medical students from SUNY Upstate Medical University. Originally housed within the Office of Undergraduate Biology, and geared towards strictly pre-health biology majors, the UCC would like to offer this level of guidance to pre-health students of all majors through the founding of this student organization by hosting student panels and organizing biannual trips to SUNY Upstate Medical campus by partnering with other clubs at Cornell.

name: Vaccine Education Initiative at Cornell
description: We aim to educate the Cornell and Ithaca communities about the benefits and risks of vaccinations, to provide service where needed in the distribution of vaccines, and to promote education and practice of behaviors beneficial to public health.

name: VET - American Association of Avian Pathologists (previously - Poultry Club)
description: The Cornell student chapter of the American Association of Avian Pathologists aims to expand the awareness of the importance of poultry medicine among members of the Cornell veterinary community. Club members will have the opportunity to listen to lectures on production and backyard poultry medicine, travel to local poultry facilities, and participate in poultry wet labs. Members will gain an appreciation for and the skills needed to be comfortable working with poultry.

name: VET - American Association of Bovine Practitioners
VET - American Association of Equine Practitioners, Student Chapter
description:
The purpose of SCAAEP is to enable veterinary students at Cornell to learn
veterinary medicine as it pertains to equine medicine, both commercial and private, to provide veterinary students with educational opportunities in the equine aspects of
veterinary medicine, to aid in the career development of students by informing them of the opportunities available in equine medicine, to enhance leadership characteristics and skills and to act as a liaison between equine veterinarians and students.

name: VET - American Association of Feline Practitioners, Student Chapter
VET - American Association of Small Ruminant Practitioners - Student Chapter
description: For those who don't have much experience with large animals, AASRP is a great way to ease into the farm animal world! AASRP is a club devoted to teaching students of all interests about the care of goats, sheep, llamas, and alpacas. Activities include various lectures on sheep/goat management, hoof trimming, sheep shearing, wetlabs, venipuncture labs, and visits to local sheep, goat and llama farms. They welcome anyone interested in learning more and interacting more with small ruminants which are rapidly becoming more popular as dairy animals and as pets.

name: VET - American Association of Swine Veterinarians
description:
To increase the knowledge of swine veterinarians by:
•	Promoting the development and availability of resources which enhance the effectiveness of professional activities
•	Creating opportunities which inspire personal and professional growth
•	Advocating science-based approaches to industry issues
•	Encouraging personal and professional interactions
•	Mentoring students, encouraging life-long careers as swine veterinarians

name: VET - American Association of Veterinary Parasitologists Cornell University Student Chapter
description: The purpose of AAVP is to share knowledge about the types of parasites veterinarians will encounter in their clinics and beyond. We also allows students interested in the profession to network with one another.

name: VET - American Society of Laboratory Animal Medicine, Student Chapter
description: The purpose of the Student Chapter of the American Society of Laboratory Animal Practitioners is to foster educational activities in the veterinary specialty of Laboratory Animal Medicine and to familiarize the members with standards, regulations and techniques pertaining to this discipline.

name: VET - Animal Behavior Club
description:
The purpose of this organization shall be to:

1) Promote the importance of animal behavior in veterinary medicine and other animal-related professions
2) Promote the use of scientifically-based, humane training techniques
3) Provide educational opportunities in relation to animal behavior, by providing guest speakers and hands-on experiences
4) Encourage camaraderie and enhance leadership characteristics among veterinary students with an interest in animal behavior
5) Act as a communication link between practicing animal behaviorists and veterinary students
6) Assist veterinary students in locating externships with practicing veterinarians with a professional interest in behavior

name: VET - Association of Avian Veterinarians, Cornell University
description: SCAAV works to enhance the educational opportunities of the veterinary students in the NYSCVM in regard to avian welfare and healthcare, specifically by informing students about veterinary problems and diseases, husbandry issues, preventative medicine, and scientific research currently encountered in dealing with both captive and wild birds.

name: VET - Association of Reptilian and Amphibian Veterinarians, ZAWS
description: We aim to train veterinary students so that they can contribute to advancing reptilian and amphibian medicine, surgery, and conservation.  We enhance the educational opportunities of the professional students in the veterinary college to learn about reptilian and amphibian medicine by hosting lectures and wet labs about veterinary problems and diseases, preventative medicine, husbandry issues, and scientific research currently encountered in dealing with both captive and wild exotic species.

name: VET - Association of Veterinary Scientists
description: To enhance collaboration and scientific growth between veterinary students, residents, and researchers interested or involved in veterinary science research

name: VET - Cardiology Club
description: The purpose of Cardiology Club is to organize cardiology rounds, lectures, and wet labs for veterinary students and other interested graduate students to get more exposure in the cardiology service.

name: VET - Dance Collective
description: The purpose of the CUCVM Dance Collective is to bring together the dance community within the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine by celebrating our enthusiasm for art, music, and dance.  As a non-audition based dance group open to students of any level and style of dance, we serve as a creative outlet for students who would like a fun and casual way to express movement and meet others with similar interests during our bi-monthly open classes.  In addition to this, the CUCVM Dance Collective also offers performance opportunities to those students who would like the chance to choreograph and perform.  Such opportunities include our annual Spring Showcase, which provides student choreographers a venue where they can present their work to the entire community.

name: VET - Guiding Eyes for the Blind at Cornell's College of Veterinary Medicine
description: Guiding Eyes for the Blind at CVM (GEB@CVM) works to connect the Cornell veterinary student body with the work of Guiding Eyes for the Blind (GEB) an internationally accredited, non-profit guide dog school based in Yorktown Heights, NY. We believe that both educating vet students about service animal training as well as directly involving vet students in the socialization of these dogs not only furthers the mission of schools like Guiding Eyes for the Blind, but also provides vet students with invaluable training in canine behavior and a unique perspective into the human-animal bond.

name: VET - Integrative Medicine Club (Previously- Holistic Veterinary Medicine Club)
description:
To advance awareness of holistic veterinary medicine among veterinary students.

To provide veterinary students with educational opportunities in holistic veterinary medicine and related subjects.

 To make available to the students an affiliation with the American Holistic Veterinary Medical Association.

To enhance leadership characteristics in its members through organization as a student club and to promote camaraderie among veterinary students with an interest in holistic veterinary medicine.

name: VET - International Veterinary Academy of Pain Management
description: As a student chapter of the International Veterinary Academy of Pain Management, we hope to familiarize students with the multi-faceted world of pain management, as it will be an integral part of their careers and lives.

name: VET - Nutritional Opportunities in (Veterinary) Medicine
description: The focus of the club is to present nutritional information from various experts, teaching students the value of nutrition in veterinary medicine, promoting interest, research, and career opportunities, and maintaining a non-biased open-mind by imparting knowledge on a variety of topics, ideas, and species.

name: VET - Psychopaths: American College of Veterinary Pathologists
description:
As a student chapter of the American College of Veterinary Pathology, the Pathology club, aim:

To encourage veterinary student involvement in the field of veterinary pathology and provide an additional opportunity for its associates to gain professional knowledge in this field.

To make available to the students the opportunities offered by the American College of Veterinary Pathologists to its Student Chapters.

To contribute to the development of the field of veterinary pathology at Cornell University through activities involving the faculty and student associates.

name: VET - Small Animal Clinical Skills Club
description:
The Small Animal Clinical Skills Clubs (SACS) at Cornell is devoted to the improvement of clinical skills students have limited opportunities to practice. 

To this end, we host lectures and wet labs; for example, in previous years have had labs on dental radiography and dental techniques such as scaling and nerve blocks. All of the labs are hands-on and allow students to practice skills on cadavers, and are taught by residents or technicians in the hospital. 

Perhaps our most important events are vaccine and SNAP test clinics that we host in the fall and spring. These are open to students, staff, and faculty of the vet school and usually draws in about 60 animals per clinic. Club members and volunteers run the entire clinic, from vaccine administration to blood draw, under the supervision of our trusted advisers, Pati Kirch, LVT/Teaching Support Specialist, and Carolyn McDaniel, VMD/Senior Lecturer, Department of Clinical Sciences.

name: VET - Society for Exotic Mammal Medicine, Cornell
description: Our organization seeks to provide learning experiences for veterinary students interested in exotic mammals. These species are not typically addressed to any great extent in the regular veterinary curriculum, so our club sponsors talks and wet labs that introduce students to common diseases and treatments relevant to their care.

name: VET - Society for Veterinary Dentistry and Oral Surgery
description: The organization's purpose is to provide the veterinary student body with opportunities to learn about veterinary dentistry and oral surgery, including basic fundamentals applicable to general practice and more specialized topics.  The organization also aims to provide hands-on experience with clinical dentistry procedures through the use of wet labs.

name: VET - Student American Veterinary Medical Association, Cornell
VET - Student Association of Aquatic Animal Medicine
description: SAAAM is a club dedicated to expanding veterinary students' knowledge of aquatic medicine.  Students will have the opportunity to attend lectures and participate in wet labs to learn more about and gain more experience with aquatic medicine.

name: VET - Student Veterinary Emergency and Critical Care Society
description: SVECCS is a student organization designed to promote the education and involvement of veterinary students in emergency and critical care medicine.

name: VET - Ultrasound A Cappella
description: Ultrasound brings together vet students to sing, perform and arrange both traditional, sacred and contemporary music in a mixed voices, non-auditioned group. We collaborate with the vet college Dance Collective and musical theatre group, Vet Players, and perform yearly for the vet school and for the Cornell community.

name: VET - Veterinarians In One Culture and Ethincity
VET - Veterinarians Interested in Developing Areas
description: VIDA promotes the awareness and understanding of veterinary medicine in developing areas. Whether it be production, conservation, basic pet health, or public health, we aim to host lectures and events which will make our community more aware of the opportunities and challenges which arise when working abroad. Hopefully we will inspire members of each incoming veterinary class to undertake international endeavors of their own, and we support talks given by those students who have had such experiences.

name: VET - Veterinary Community Sustainability Club
description: The purpose of this club is to educate and promote sustainable practices among veterinary students and other community members at the Cornell University College of Veterinary Medicine through lectures, labs, documentaries, and student events.

name: VET - Veterinary Education Club
description: Cornell's Veterinary Education Club aims to serve our Student Body through events and activities that enhance student wellness while also integrating our students into the local community. We work with the Office of Student Academic Services to promote relevant programming, and we also coordinate with other organizations to promote events related to student wellness. The Veterinary Education Club also focuses on educating the local community about current veterinary issues via outreach programs. We work with local 4-H clubs, the undergraduate Pre-Veterinary Society, and this year we will be working with some of the local elementary schools.  This is a fantastic outlet for current veterinary students who are interested in becoming involved in academia, clinical instruction, and/or public outreach.

name: VET - Veterinary Internal Medicine, Student Chapter
description:
The purpose of the Chapter is to promote the specialties of cardiology, neurology,
oncology, large animal internal medicine, and small animal internal medicine through the
advancement of knowledge to veterinary medical students.

name: VET - Veterinary One Health Association   (Previously -Veterinary Public Health Association)
VET - Veterinary Players
description: We are a group of vet students and some faculty and staff who share a love for theater. We put on a production each year for the enjoyment of the Cornell and Ithaca community.

name: VET - Veterinary Radiology Club, Cornell University
description: The purpose of the Cornell University Veterinary Radiology Club is to promote and encourage the study of radiology and other diagnostic imaging modalities by exploring all aspects of diagnostic imaging and radiotherapy through presentations, learning modules, and hands- on experience. Diagnostic imaging modalities include: small and large animal diagnostic radiology, diagnostic ultrasound, nuclear medicine, computed tomography, and magnetic resonance imaging.

name: VET - Wildlife Disease Associate, Student Chapter
VET - Women's Veterinary Leadership Development Initiative, Student Chapter
Volunteers Around the World Dental Outreach
description: The purpose of this organization is to provide Pre-Dental students, or any other students who might be interested in the field of dentistry, the opportunity to shadow and assist professional dentists in communities of a foreign setting. Volunteers Around the World (VAW) is an NGO (Non-Governmental Organization) devoted to improving the standard of living for those that live in some of the most poverty stricken communities of the world. The overall focus is to provide communities with access to medical treatment, medication, nutritional security, clean water, and health education.

name: Von Cramm Cooperative Hall
description:
Statement on the Cooperative Identity

Definition A co-operative is an autonomous association of persons united voluntarily to meet their common economic, social, and cultural needs and aspirations through a jointly-owned and democratically- controlled enterprise.

Values Co-operatives are based on the values of self-help, self- responsibility, democracy, equality, equity, and solidarity. In the tradition of their founders, co-operative members believe in the ethical values of honesty, openness, social responsibility, and caring for others.

Principles The co-operative principles are guidelines by which co-operatives put their values into practice.

name: Votes, Cornell
description: We are an organization which aims to increase voter registration across campus by providing information and facilities so that individuals are better equipped to register and fulfill their civic responsibility by voting.

name: Wait Terrace Cooperative
description: To facilitate learning and community in a residential context.

name: Wanawake Wa Wari Cooperative
description: Wanawake Wa Wari was originally founded in 1968 by a group of Black women who felt the need for an atmosphere that promoted self-awareness and personal confidence.  Since that time Wari has served as a place where women of African descent have prepared for the world academically, culturally, and socially.  It has also provided an atmosphere where women feel comfortable to deal with the issues that relate to their lives and history in the Ithaca community and beyond.  We are striving to continue this tradition.

name: Weill-Ithaca Network
description:
Our mission is to provide a gateway for Cornell pre-medical undergraduates to gain exposure to the medical field by pairing students with a Weill Cornell medical student mentor and organizing events that include trips to the Weill Cornell campus in NYC.

The broader vision of WIN is to bridge the geographical divide between the two campuses, thereby facilitating greater intercampus dialogue and collaboration at the student level. Distance should not become a significant obstacle for students' academic and professional growth. We hope to expand to include Physicians Assistants and PhD mentorship programs with Weill Cornell in the future.

name: West Coast Swing Dance Network
description: Our purpose is to teach and promote West Coast Swing Dance in the Cornell and Ithaca communities through inclusive teaching methods and a welcoming, non-competitive environment.

name: Wildlife Society, Cornell University Student Chapter
Willard Straight Hall Student Union Board of Directors (SUB)
Women's Club Basketball, Cornell University
description: The purpose of our organization is to provide women basketball players in the Cornell community to opportunity to play fun, yet competitive basketball.

name: Women's Club Softball, Cornell
description: We provide an opportunity for competitive fast-pitch softball that is not as intensive or time-consuming as fast-pitch on the varsity level. Our mission is to create a welcoming and friendly yet still competitive environment for players who would like to continue their softball career post-high school but at a more relaxed level of commitment than the varsity team.

name: Women's Club Volleyball, Cornell
description: We look to provide a way for girls to keep playing volleyball competitively. We practice twice a week and travel to tournaments on weekends.

name: Women's Finance Organization, Cornell University
description: The purpose of the organization is to educate women about the different fields on Finance that they can go into upon graduating Cornell by inviting guest speakers to speak of their experiences. Additionally, we want to create a mentorship program where women working in the field would be advisors to Cornell undergraduates looking to pursue careers in Finance.

name: Women's Health Initiative, Cornell University
description: We aim to address women's health issues through education, advocacy, and community service.

name: Women's Ice Hockey Club, Cornell
description: To enjoy the sport of ice hockey, learn and improve skills, and create a successful team.

name: Women's Sevens Rugby Club, Cornell
description: CWSRC is a team of fifteen women who meet weekly to practice and compete in matches. No experience necessary.

name: Women's Swim Club, Cornell
description: The Women's Cornell Club Swim Team is a Cornell club sports team where any prior competitive swimmers can continue to train for competition with a team. The Women's team will practice weekly and compete in intercollegiate meets throughout the semester, representing Cornell, improving as a swimmer and bonding as a team.

name: Women's Ultimate Frisbee, Cornell Thorny Roses
X-ray Structure and Dynamics Journal Club
description: This club functions as a resource for researchers in the field of X-ray structure and dynamics to convene and discuss current scientific literature in the field. The aims of this club are to allow for a space for collaborative, interdisciplinary science at Cornell.

name: Youth Decide
description: Promote healthy, happiness-inducing behaviors for youth outside Cornell University and young adults at Cornell University by educating effectively on salient public health issues; leveraging the Social Development Strategy to build positive communities and robust relationships; advocating for public policies that stymie unhealthy behaviors or encourage healthy behaviors; and adopting other strategies that might advance our aforementioned mission.
